questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not likely to cause an abnormal sign pertaining to the clinical finding being tested in the image below?
questions.solution:
By asking the patient to keep the dorsal surfaces of his fingers opposed (Schamroth sign), the finding being elicited is clubbing. Clubbing is seen in conditions like lung abscess, cystic fibrosis, and aortic aneurysm, but not in irritable bowel syndrome.

Digital clubbing is a focal bulbous enlargement of the terminal segments of the fingers and/or toes. It occurs due to the proliferation of connective tissue between the nail matrix and the distal phalanx. Clubbed fingers are also known as watch-glass nails, drumstick fingers, and Hippocratic fingers/nails.

Hypoxia causes increased release of platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) and vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). This leads to increased vascularity, permeability, and connective tissue changes.

The image below shows clubbing.

Clinical methods to elicit clubbing are:

  • Schamroth sign: It is performed by placing the dorsal surfaces of terminal phalanges of corresponding right and left fingers together. Normal fingers create a diamond-shaped window, but this window is obliterated in clubbed fingers. 
  • Lovibond's angle/Profile sign: It is the angle made by the nail as it exists from the proximal nail fold. Normally, this angle is usually less than 180°. In true clubbing, it is more than 180°.
  • Hyponychial angle: This is constructed by drawing a line from the distal digital crease to the cuticle and another line from the cuticle to the hyponychium (the thickened stratum corneum of the epidermis under the free edge of the nail). The normal angle is less than 192°.
  • Phalangeal depth ratio: This is defined by the ratio of the digit's depth measured at the nail bed and distal interphalangeal joint. Normally, the depth at the distal interphalangeal joint is more than that at the nail bed. A phalangeal depth ratio of more than 1 is indicative of clubbing.
  • Digital index: This is the sum of the phalangeal depth ratios for all 10 fingers. A digital index of 10.2 or more is indicative of clubbing. This is more specific for clubbing than pharyngeal depth ratio.

The causes of clubbing are:

  • Pulmonary
    • Bronchogenic carcinoma
    • Mesothelioma
    • Lung abscess, empyema, bronchiectasis
    • Cystic fibrosis
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Diffuse pulmonary disease - pulmonary fibrosis, asbestosis
  • GI
    • Inflammatory bowel disease - ulcerative colitis, Crohn's disease
    • Sprue, celiac disease
    • Gastric and colonic carcinoma
    • Cirrhosis
    • Chronic active hepatitis
  • Cardiovascular
    • Cyanotic congenital heart disease
    • Infective endocarditis
    • Aortic aneurysm
    • Arteriovenous malformations
    • Atrial myxoma
  • Endocrine
    • Hyperthyroidism - Grave’s disease
  • CNS
    • Hemiplegia (unilateral clubbing)

questions.text: Which of the following is against the principles for the use of antibiotic therapy in surgical infection?

choices.text: Antibiotics do not replace surgical drainage of infection
Only spreading infection or sytemic infection justify use of antibiotics
Pus for culture should be taken after antibiotic cover is started

questions.solution:
Pus for culture should be taken before antibiotic cover is started.

Principles for the use of antibiotic therapy:

  • Surgical drainage of infection cannot be replaced by antibiotics. 
  • The use of antibiotics is justified only if spreading infections or signs of systemic infection are present.
  • The organism and sensitivity should be determined.
  • Tissue or pus culture should be taken before antibiotic cover is started.

questions.text: A  patient was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. His CT scan is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT image shows a crescent-shaped lesion that crosses suture lines and is indicative of acute subdural hematoma/hemorrhage.

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH) is a collection of blood between the dura and the arachnoid layers of the meninges. Most commonly, it results from the rupture of cortical bridging veins. Non-contrast CT is the investigation of choice.

Radiographic features of subdural hemorrhages:

  • Crescent-like distribution around the periphery of the brain.
  • They are not limited by sutures.
  • Crescent-shaped hypodense lesion on axial CT: Chronic subdural hemorrhage
  • Crescent-shaped hyperdense collections on CT: Acute subdural hemorrhage. 

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hemorrhage (ICH)

Extradural hemorrhage (EDH): 

  • Source: Arterial bleed
  • MC- Middle meningeal artery 
  • Cause- Trauma 
  • Clinical features: Lucid interval is characteristic 
  • CT – Lentiform opacity 
  • Treatment: A large or rapidly evolving EDH requires surgical evacuation

 

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous bleed 
  • Bridging dural veins 
  • Causes: Trauma, anticoagulants, antiplatelets, alcohol abuse, shaken baby syndrome 
  • Clinical features
    • Acute SDH: may be associated with lucid interval
    • Chronic SDH: drowsiness, headache
  • CT- crescentic opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)

  • Source: Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – Trauma
    • 2nd MC – Rupture of berry aneurysm
  • MC sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery 
  • Clinical features: Thunderclap headache with neck stiffness +/- FND 
  • Investigations:
    • Non-contrast CT brain,
    • CSF xanthochromia (peaks in 2 days and subsides in 2 weeks) 
  • Treatment:
    • Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm,
    • Triple H therapy – hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution to prevent vasospasm 

 

Intraparenchymal hemorrhage- (MC type of ICH)

  • Source- Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – hypertension
    • Trauma, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, bleeding disorders, neoplasms, vascular malformations 
  • MC sites:
    • Putamen (basal ganglia)
    • Thalamus
    • Cerebellum
    • Pons 
  • Treatment:
    • Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP or fresh platelets as required
    • Surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoms >3 cm in size

questions.text: A 45-year-old man had severe hypothyroidism.  His arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis shows very low pO2 and high pCO2 levels.  Which of the following types of respiratory failure is likely to be present in him?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of severe hypothyroidism with hypoxemia and hypercapnia is suggestive of type 2 respiratory failure. 

Type II respiratory failure occurs as a consequence of alveolar hypoventilation and results from the inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively. The mechanism of type II respiratory failure in severe hypothyroidism can be due to poor response of the central nervous system to hypoxia and hypercapnia, aw well as reduced strength of the respiratory muscles.

Other causes for diminished CNS drive to breathe:

  • Drug overdose
  • Brainstem injury
  • Sleep-disordered breathing 

Reduced strength for respiration can be due to

  • Impaired neuromuscular transmission (e.g., myasthenia gravis, Guillain-Barré syndrome, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis)
  • Respiratory muscle weakness (e.g., myopathy, electrolyte derangements, fatigue, )

The overall load on the respiratory system that can facilitate type 2 respiratory failure can be classified as follows:

  • Resistive loads as in bronchospasm
  • Loads due to reduced lung compliance as in alveolar edema, atelectasis, intrinsic positive end-expiratory pressure
  • Loads due to reduced chest wall compliance as in pneumothorax, pleural effusion, abdominal distention
  • Loads due to increased minute ventilation requirements as in pulmonary embolus with increased dead-space fraction, sepsis

Treatment:

Reversing the underlying causes of ventilatory failure remains the mainstay treatment for type 2 respiratory failure. Non-invasive positive-pressure ventilation with a tight-fitting facial or nasal mask and avoidance of endotracheal intubation often stabilizes patients with type 2 respiratory failure. This approach is beneficial in treating patients with exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

I Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure Alveolar flooding and subsequent intrapulmonary shunt physiology. Sepsis, gastric aspiration, pneumonia, near-drowning, multiple blood transfusions and pancreatitis.

questions.text: An asthma patient comes to the clinic because she has been experiencing daily daytime exacerbations which limit her activity. She also complains of exacerbations of asthma during most nights of the week. Her regular medications include a formoterol inhaler and a daily medium dose of inhaled corticosteroid (ICS), however she often forgets to take it. Which of the following medications is not preferred in her management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of daily daytime exacerbations with activity restriction and daily nighttime exacerbations is suggestive of severe persistent asthma or uncontrolled asthma. Low-dose ICS with salbutamol is not preferred as reliever therapy in severe persistent asthma in non-adherent patients.

As per Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA) guidelines, formoterol + low-dose ICS is the preferred reliever in all cases of asthma irrespective of the severity of the disease. Short-acting β2 agonist is an alternative reliever that can be used to manage all cases of asthma, provided that patient adherence to daily therapy can be assured.

Asthma is categorized as intermittent if the patient has daytime symptoms up to 2 times per week, and nighttime awakenings due to symptoms up to 2 times per month. If the symptoms are more severe than this, then the patient's asthma is categorized to be persistent. Persistent asthma is further divided into the following based on the severity of the symptoms:

Category Mild persistent Moderate persistent Severe persistent
Daytime symptoms More than 2 times per week but less than daily Daily Present throughout the day along with severe restriction of daily activities
Nighttime awakenings 3-4 times a month but not every week Once per week Almost every night
Treatment Low dose ICS + formoterol as needed Low dose ICS + formoterol daily Medium to high dose ICS + formoterol/LABA daily + add-on drugs

Inhaled corticosteroids are the backbone of asthma management as they alleviate the symptoms of inflammation and improve lung function. However, there is an increased mortality risk with only corticosteroids and better patient outcomes are seen when a beta agonist is added. 

Add-on drugs for severe or uncontrolled asthma:

  • Anticholinergics: Ipratropium bromide, Tiotropium bromide
  • Corticosteroids (Systemic): Prednisolone, Hydrocortisone
  • anti-IgE - Omalizumab
  • anti-IL5 - Mepolizumab, Reslizumab
  • anti-IL4 receptor - Dupilumab

Important Update:

According to GINA 2019, Short-acting beta 2 agonists (SABA) have no role in treating acute exacerbations. Even though SABA provides short-term relief of symptoms, there is strong evidence that SABA-only treatment increases the risk of exacerbations. 

GINA now recommends symptom-driven (in mild asthma), a daily dose of ICS containing treatment to reduce the risk of serious exacerbations. This is said to be the most important change in asthma management in 30 years.

questions.text: A known cardiac patient who underwent PCI with stent placement 6 months ago is on regular aspirin ever since. He is posted for emergency hernia surgery for the strangulated hernia. What would be your advice regarding aspirin?

choices.text: Stop aspirin and replace with heparin
Stop aspirin and give platelet transfusion

questions.solution:
If a patient on a coronary stent taking aspirin is posted for surgery, aspirin should be continued even on the day of surgery to avoid the risk of stent rethrombosis, myocardial infarction or death.

Antiplatelet drugs should not be interrupted in patients with coronary stents without consultation with a cardiologist.

  • Drug-eluting coronary stents require antiplatelet administration for at least 6 months.
  • Bare metal stents for at least one month.

Ideally, elective surgery is avoided for one month in patients with bare coronary stents and one year for those with drug-eluting stents. But emergency surgeries cannot be postponed.

Note: The drug-eluting stents delay this endothelial growth by eluting drugs like sirolimus/paclitaxel etc and thereby reduce the risk of endothelial overgrowth causing occlusion. But this prolonged lack of endothelial lining causes an increased risk of thrombosis and hence a longer duration of antiplatelet therapy is required with drug-eluting stents.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents with weakness of the left upper limb. On examination, the blood pressure recorded on the left upper limb was found to be lower than that of the right upper limb. Her aortic arch angiogram showed narrowing of the arch of the aorta and subclavian artery. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and radiological findings are suggestive of Takayasu arteritis. It involves the arch of the aorta and its branches, usually the subclavian artery, leading to reduced blood pressure and weak pulse in the affected upper limb.

Takayasu arteritis is a chronic inflammatory medium- and large-vessel vasculitis that commonly affects adolescents and young females. It mainly involves the aortic arch and its branches. Depending on the artery occluded, patients present with the following symptoms:

  • Subclavian artery (most common) - pain, numbness, claudication, and weak or absent radial pulses on the affected side
  • Common carotid artery - visual symptoms, syncope, and stroke
  • Abdominal aorta, superior mesenteric artery, and coeliac axis - abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting
  • Renal artery - hypertension and renal failure
  • Aortic arch or root - aortic insufficiency, heart failure
  • Pulmonary artery - atypical chest pain, dyspnea
  • Coronary artery - chest pain, myocardial infarction
  • Iliac artery - Leg claudication, weak/absent pulses in the periphery

Patients also have constitutional symptoms such as malaise, fever, night sweats, weight loss, etc.

Lab reports reveal an elevated ESR level, anemia, and elevated immunoglobulin levels. Arteriography is done as a confirmatory test.

Treatment includes glucocorticoid therapy, methotrexate, immunotherapy with anti-TNF agents, and surgery of the stenosed vessels.

Other options:

Option A: Giant cell arteritis (GCA), also known as temporal arteritis, is an inflammation of medium and large-sized vessels. It is more common in women and people aged >50 years.

Option C: Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is necrotizing arteritis of the medium-sized blood vessels. It can affect the skin, peripheral nerves, renal vessels, mesenteric vessels, heart, and brain. Lungs are usually spared in PAN. The disease initially starts with non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, arthralgia, and myalgia. Nerve involvement results in mononeuritis multiplex. Depending on the artery involved, patients may develop the following symptoms:

Skin findings - ulcers, digital gangrene, subcutaneous nodules, and livedo reticularis
Renal arteries - hypertension and renal failure
Mesenteric arteries - abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bleeding, and a bowel perforation

Option D: Kawasaki disease is an acute self-limiting illness affecting medium-sized arteries in children less than 4 years of age. Coronary arteries are affected which may cause aneurysm, thrombosis or myocardial infarction.

choices.text: Gives results pretty early in a pregnancy
Suitable for the detection of chromosomal abnormalities
Suitable for the detection of inborn errors of metabolism
Suitable for the detection of neural tube defects

questions.text:
A 40-year-old lady who recently went in for an IUCD contraception has increasing pelvic discomfort and pain just a few days before her menses begin. The pain is relieved once the menses starts. What is the clinical diagnosis in this case?

IUCD: Intrauterine contraceptive device
questions.solution:
Pelvic discomfort and pain just a few days before menses are suggestive of congestive dysmenorrhea.

Dysmenorrhea is defined as cramping pain that occurs during menstruation.

It can be classified as:

A. Etiological:

  • Primary dysmenorrhea is a type of dysmenorrhoea that is not associated with any pelvic pathology. It affects women in the age group of 18 to 25 years, with ovulatory cycles.
  • Secondary (Acquired) dysmenorrhea is associated with the presence of pelvic pathologies such as fibroids, adenomyosis, pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), and endometriosis. 

B.  Clinical:

  • Spasmodic dysmenorrhea is the most common and is characterized by cramping pain on the first and second days of menstruation. 
  • Congestive dysmenorrhea presents as worsening pelvic discomfort and pelvic pain, a few days before the onset of menses followed by relief of the symptoms. This is seen in PID, IUCD users, varicosities of pelvic veins, pelvic endometriosis, and fibroids. 
  • Membranous dysmenorrhea is rare and is characterized by crampy pain that occurs with the passage of the endometrium as a cast at the time of menstruation.

Primary dysmenorrhea can be managed with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), combined oral contraceptive pills, and progestin-only pills. GnRH agonists and androgens are also useful. Surgical management includes hysterectomy and is indicated if not responding to medical management. In secondary dysmenorrhea, treating the cause is needed.

Fibromyalgia is a disorder with diffuse musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. It is associated with irritable bowel syndrome, anxiety, and depression. There is no cure for fibromyalgia as of now, although the symptoms can be controlled by medications. Researchers believe that fibromyalgia amplifies painful sensations by affecting the way your brain processes pain signals.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the placental separation method shown in the image below:

choices.text: It is commonly known as Mathews-Duncan method
Occurs during fourth stage of labor
The fetal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva

questions.solution:
The above image shows the Schultze method of placental separation. In this method, the fetal surface of the placenta appears first at the vulva.

Placental separation occurs during the third stage of labor. There are two mechanisms by which placental separation may occur:

A. Central separation of the placenta, known as Schultze method

B. Marginal separation of the placenta, known as Mathews-Duncan method.

Schultze method:

  • The separation begins at the centre of the placenta (fetal surface). Hence, this is the first part to descend and appear at vulva.
  • The blood collects into a membranous sac behind the placenta, leading to the formation of retroplacental clot.
  • Bleeding does not occur until the placenta is completely extruded.

Mathews-Duncan method:

  • The separation of the placenta begins at the peripheral edge of the placenta. Hence, the maternal surface appears first.
  • The blood collects between the membranes and the uterine wall, and escapes out from the vagina. There is no formation of retroplacental clot and the bleeding is profuse in this method of placental separation.
  • It is much less common than Schultze method.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with the following deformity. She complains of joint pain and stiffness in the fingers for 5-6 years. She reports that stiffness is more in the early morning and improves on performing household activities. What is the most common extra-articular manifestation seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with image showing swan neck deformity (hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint) is classically seen in rheumatoid arthritis. The most common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis is subcutaneous nodules. 

Subcutaneous nodules are generally firm, non-tender nodules that are adherent to the periosteum, tendons, or bursae. They develop in areas that are subjected to repeated trauma or irritation such as the forearm, sacral prominences, and Achilles tendon. Nodules can also develop in the lungs, pleura, pericardium, and peritoneum. Infection, gangrene and malignant transformation can be rarely seen with subcutaneous nodules.

Other extraarticular manifestations seen in rheumatoid arthritis are:

  • Sjogren syndrome - it presents with keratoconjunctivitis sicca or xerostomia
  • Rheumatoid vasculitis - it presents as petechiae, purpura, digital infarcts, gangrene, livedo reticularis
  • Pulmonary -  
    • Pleuritis - most common pulmonary manifestation
    • Interstitial lung diseases
  • Cardiac - 
    • Pericarditis - most common cardiac manifestation
    • Cardiomyopathy
    • Mitral regurgitation
    • Coronary artery disease
  • Hematologic - 
    • Normochromic normocytic anemia - most common hematologic abnormality 
    • Felty's syndrome - is a triad of neutropenia, splenomegaly, and nodular rheumatoid arthritis. It is a rare manifestation
    • Lymphoma

Patients developing extra-articular manifestations are associated with risk factors such as: History of smoking, early onset of physical disability, rheumatoid factor positive and anti-CCP antibody positive.

Related Pearl: Most commons conditions in Rheumatoid Arthritis

M/C extra-articular manifestation Subcutaneous nodules
M/C pulmonary manifestation Pleuritis
M/C cardiac involvement Pericarditis
M/C valvular lesion Mitral regurgitation
M/C hematologic abnormality Normochromic, normocytic anemia
M/C part of the spine involved Cervical spine
M/C type of lymphoma Diffuse large B cell lymphoma
M/C cause of death Cardiovascular disease

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

NSAIDs - Analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive agents for the management of uncontrollable symptoms and useful in an acute flare.

Glucocorticoids - Used during an acute flare for rapid disease control and as initial therapy before the onset of the effect of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed to control disease in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone- oral 
  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     
DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs

Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX): It is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine: It used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine: A salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide: A pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

 

Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists: Used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept: A T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab: An anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra: An IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with an anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists: Tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

 

Small molecules: Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, barcitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman presents with chronic fatigue and easy bruising. She has had surgery for ovarian cancer 7 years ago along with chemoradiation. Her lab reports reveal pancytopenia and bone marrow biopsy shows the following finding. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of therapy-related myelodysplastic syndrome (t-MDS).

The bone marrow biopsy stained with Perl's Prussian blue shows ringed sideroblasts. They are erythroblasts with iron-laden mitochondria visible as perinuclear granules as shown in the image below.

Myelodysplastic syndrome is a group of clonal stem cell disorders characterized by maturation defects, associated with ineffective hematopoiesis.

It is of two types:

  • Primary MDS - develops slowly, usually after 50 years of age.
  • Secondary or therapy-related MDS (t-MDS) - develops 2 to 8 years after toxic drug or radiation exposure with poor prognosis

Patients usually present with weakness, infections and hemorrhages due to pancytopenia. Both types of MDS have a high risk of transformation to acute myeloid leukemia (AML). However, most frequent and rapid transformation occurs in therapy-related MDS (t-MDS).

VEXAS syndrome (vacuoles, E1 enzyme, X-linked, autoinflammatory, somatic) is a Novel disorder discovered in 2020. It is an adult-onset inflammatory disease with clinical features that bridge rheumatologic & hematologic conditions. VEXAS may be a prototype for new class of “hematoinflammatory diseases.” These diseases would be defined by somatic mutations in hematopoietic cells, systemic inflammation, & potential to evolve into overt myelodysplastic, myeloproliferative, or lymphoproliferative disease.

questions.text:
A 69-year-old diabetic patient has come to you with excruciating right ear pain and right-sided facial palsy. Otoscopic examination of the ear shows granulations on the floor of the external auditory canal. Choose the correct statements regarding this condition.
  1. It is a malignant condition.
  2. It can occur in immunocompromised patients.
  3. Technetium 99 scan is used to monitor the disease.
  4. Gallium-67 scan is useful in the follow-up of the patient.
  5. Prolonged antibiotic therapy is given.
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of an elderly diabetic patient with excruciating ear pain, facial palsy, and granulations on the floor of the external auditory canal points toward the diagnosis of malignant otitis externa. The correct statements are 2, 4 and 5.

Malignant otitis externa is an infective condition (not malignant). Technetium 99 scan is not used to monitor the disease. 

It is an inflammatory condition caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa in elderly diabetics and immunocompromised patients. It is characterised by excruciating ear pain, profuse discharge and granulations on the floor of the external ear canal.

Necrosis of bone aids in the spread of infection. Infection may spread to the skull base and jugular foramen causing multiple cranial nerve palsies. Facial paralysis is the most common nerve palsy seen.

Gallium-67 scan is useful in the diagnosis and follow-up of the patient. It can be repeated every 3 weeks to monitor the disease and response to treatment. Technetium 99 bone scan reveals bone infection, but the test remains positive for a year or so and cannot be used to monitor the disease.

Treatment includes:

  • Control of diabetes.
  • Toilet of the ear canal. Remove discharge, debris and granulations or at dead tissue or bone.
  • Antibiotic treatment against P. aeruginosa for 6-8 weeks or more. If the patient is not responsive, treatment should be based on culture and sensitivity of ear discharge.

Antibiotics which are usually effective against pseudomonas aeroginosa are:

  • Gentamicin combined with ticarcillin (IV)
  • Third-generation cephalosporins (IV) e.g. ceftriaxone, ceftazidime along with an aminoglycoside
  • Fluoroquinolones (ciprofloxacin, ofloxacin and levofloxacin) combined with rifampin (Oral)

questions.text: A couple presented in the outpatient department with infertility. The husband's semen analysis was normal. The wife reported menorrhagia and a hysterosalpingogram showed a tobacco pouch appearance with distal dilatation of the tubes.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario along with a hysterosalpingogram showing a tobacco pouch appearance is diagnostic of tubal salpingitis, most likely tubercular salpingitis.

Hydrosalpinx occurs following acute salpingitis. The tubes are retort-shaped due to dilatation of the ampulla and filled with a clear fluid. The interstitial end of the tube is open whereas the fimbrial end is indrawn and closed. This permits the dye to enter but not exit the tube during hysterosalpingography. 

Genital tuberculosis is almost always secondary to the primary focus. The fallopian tubes are the first to be involved and are bilaterally affected.

It is secondary to hematogenous spread from a primary focus. The ampullary part of the tube appears dilated with the fimbrial end open and pouting. This gives the characteristic tobacco-pouch appearance as seen in the image below.

HSG should not be performed in a suspected case of genital tuberculosis as it causes dissemination of the infection. This further increases the damage to the fallopian tubes.

If performed, HSG findings in tubercular salpingitis include:

  • A rigid non-peristaltic pipe-like tube (lead pipe appearance)
  • Beading and variation in the filling defect
  • Calcification of the tube, Coiling of the tubes
  • Cornual block
  • Tobacco-pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx
  • Tubal diverticula and/or fluffiness of tubal outline.

questions.text:
A young woman at 28 weeks of gestation comes with complaints of fever and jaundice for 1 week. She has no history of pale stools or pruritus. Investigations reveal the following. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Aminotransferases: 2500 IU/L
Total bilirubin : 8 mg/dl
Prothrombin time: 15 seconds
Hemoglobin: 13 g/dl
Platelet count: 100,000/mm3
D dimer: Normal
questions.solution:
Viral hepatitis in pregnancy is characterized by fever, very high aminotransferases, elevated total bilirubin, and markers of liver dysfunction such as elevated prothrombin time and thrombocytopenia. 

The clinical and laboratory findings of acute liver diseases in pregnancy are as follows:

Other options:

Option B: AFLP (Acute fatty liver of pregnancy) is a common cause of acute liver failure in pregnancy. It usually occurs in the later stages of pregnancy, particularly in the third trimester. Patients present with persistent nausea and vomiting, progressive jaundice and epigastric pain. Features like hypoglycemia, hypertension, proteinuria, and edema can also be present. Symptoms may progress to fulminant hepatic failure with encephalopathy, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and death.

Option C: HELLP is an acronym for hemolysis (H), elevated liver enzymes (EL), and low platelet count (LP). It usually occurs in patients with severe preeclampsia. The patients typically present with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting. Hypertension and proteinuria are seen but may be absent in some cases.

Option D: Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy occurs during the late 2nd and early 3rd trimesters. It usually presents with intense pruritus after 30 weeks of gestation over the palms and soles and is worse at night. Other symptoms include anorexia, nausea, fatigue, right upper quadrant pain, dark urine, and pale stool.

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient comes for a prenatal exam at 27 weeks of gestation. USG shows a monochorionic multifetal pregnancy with the largest vertical pocket of 10 cm in one twin and 1 cm in the other twin. Both twins appear morphologically normal although growth discordance is identified. What is the likely underlying cause of this finding?

choices.text: Single uterine artery in the small fetus

questions.solution:
This patient presenting with monochorionic multifetal gestations and growth discordance with the largest vertical pocket (LVP) of 10 cm in one twin, indicated polyhydramnios, and 1 cm in the other twin, indicating oligohydramnios, should raise concerns for interfetal transfusion syndrome also known as twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS). 

TTTS is a clinicopathological condition found only in monozygotic twins in which one twin appears to bleed into the other via a placental vascular anastomosis.

Clinical signs of twin transfusion syndrome appear when there is a hemodynamic imbalance brought on by unidirectional deep arteriovenous anastomoses. As a result, the donor twin shrinks with oligohydramnios, anemia, hypotension, and hypovolemia, while the receptor twin grows larger with polyhydramnios, polycythemic, hypertensive, and hypervolemic characteristics. Due to severe oligohydramnios, the donor twin may seem "stuck". The hemoglobin concentration differential between the two is typically greater than 5 g%, and the estimated fetal weight discrepancy is at least 25%.

The diagnosis of TTTS is based on two sonographic criteria. First is the identification of a monochorionic pregnancy, and second is the identification of polyhydramnios (LVP > 8 cm) in one fetus and oligohydramnios (LVP < 2 cm) in the other. Growth discordance is seen but is not a diagnostic criterion. 

Management of this condition is usually with obliteration of some of the shared vessels as it can lead to heart failure in the hyperperfused twin.

Other options:

Option B: Twin reversed arterial perfusion (TRAP) is a complication seen in monochorionic multifetal gestation. It is caused by a large artery-to-artery or vein-to-vein placental shunt. Unlike TTTS, there is no arteriovenous anastomosis. The recipient twin lacks a cardiac system, while the donor twin does the work of supplying blood for both twins. Blood from the donor twin reaches the iliac vessels of the recipient twin through the umbilical arteries. Therefore the recipient twin appears malformed, as only the lower body is developed, while the upper body is poorly developed. The donor twin may show signs of heart failure.

Option C: Single uterine artery is a malformation seen in some fetuses with an associated genetic condition. However, the presence of a small and large fetus should raise concerns about interfetal transfusion syndrome.

Option D: Twin anemia–polycythemia sequence (TAPS) is similar to TTTS, where the donor twin is anemic and smaller than the recipient twin, which is polycythemic. However, unlike TTTS, the amniotic fluid volumes in TAPS are similar for both fetuses.

questions.text: A young woman has a fear of getting into elevators since birth. She prefers stairs over elevators. She is also scared to use public transport. What is this condition known as?
questions.solution:
This woman with a fear of elevators and public transport, but prefers stairs over elevators from where she can escape easily has agoraphobia.

Agoraphobia is the anxiety that occurs when one is in a public or crowded place, from which a potential escape is difficult, or help may not be readily available. example crowds, public places, or public transportation.

It is more common in women. It leads to severe restrictions on the individual’s travel and daily routine.

Option A: Claustrophobia - Fear of closed spaces

Option B: Aerophobia - Fear of flying 

Option D: Ailurophobia - Fear of cats

Note: Specific phobia is the most common type of phobia. Agoraphobia is not a specific phobia and is classified separately under anxiety disorders.

Some special terms:

  • Acrophobia: Fear of heights
  • Agoraphobia: Fear of the places from where easy escape is not possible
  • Xenophobia: fear of strangers
  • Zoophobia: fear of animals
  • Claustrophobia: fear of closed spaces

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with complaints of difficulty in opening his mouth, restricted tongue movements, and a burning sensation in the mouth while eating food. He is a smoker and chews pan masala. On examination, scarring is present in the oral cavity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is oral submucous fibrosis. It is a premalignant lesion of the oral cavity, in which fibrous bands are formed beneath the oral mucosa.
Risk factors are

  • Betel nut
  • Chilli
  • Tobacco
  • Vitamin deficiency

Clinical features include ankyloglossia, trismus, soreness, and a burning sensation in the mouth while eating.

Management includes intralesional steroids, vitamin supplements, and surgical excision.

Option A: Plummer-Vinson syndrome is characterized by post cricoid web that is associated with iron deficiency anemia, glossitis, and koilonychia. It usually presents as dysphagia.

Option B: Proliferative verrucous leucoplakia appears as a white patchy lesion, that cannot be rubbed off.

Option D: Erythroplakia is seen as bright red velvety plaque in the oral cavity.

questions.text: A 57 year old male is brought with complaints of progressive loss of cognitive function. His symptoms began 2 years ago, and he had a noticeable worsening again 1 year ago and 6 months ago with progressive worsening of symptoms. He is oriented only to person and place but not time. He has a past history of diabetes and hypertension. Which of the following investigations should be done next?
questions.solution:
In the given patient, who is a known case of hypertension and diabetes mellitus, now presenting with stepwise deteriorating cognitive function with 3 different discrete time periods where he had a noticeable worsening of symptoms, the likely diagnosis is vascular dementia. Diagnosis of vascular dementia is usually made by finding lesions via an MRI of the brain.

Vascular dementia is the second most prevalent form of dementia, after Alzheimer disease. It includes any dementia which is primarily caused by a cerebrovascular disease or impaired cerebral blood flow. Any cause of ischemic stroke (like atheroembolism), intracerebral hemorrhage, or subarachnoid hemorrhage can cause vascular dementia if the underlying injury to the brain is severe enough. Aside from a clinical stroke, cerebral small vessel diseases such as arteriosclerosis and cerebral amyloid angiopathy can also lead to vascular dementia.

The patient will likely have a vascular risk factor (hypertension, diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia, tobacco use or atrial fibrillation), a history of prior stroke, or transient ischemic attack. There will usually be a stepwise decline in the patient's mental state due to a series of unrecognized strokes. Executive functions (such as planning and organization) are likely to be affected more and early in the disease course. This is in contrast to Alzheimer's disease, where there's a slow progression and recent episodic memory is affected first.

Diagnosis is usually clinical based on the history but lesions in the brain can be visualised by an MRI. 

Treatment is mainly aimed at preventing further strokes via pharmacotherapy and supportive therapy.

questions.text: During resuscitation, when is the given position indicated?

choices.text: Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing absent
Unconsciousness with pulse present and breathing absent
Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing present
Unconsciousness with pulse absent and breathing present

questions.solution:
The position illustrated in the picture is known as the recovery position, and it is used in the management of patients who are unconscious but with pulse present and breathing present.

The recovery position can help prevent complications such as aspiration and airway obstruction in unconscious individuals. Additionally, it is crucial to monitor the patient's airway, breathing, and circulation continuously while they are in the recovery position and seek immediate medical assistance. An unresponsive patient who is breathing spontaneously in the supine position is at risk of airway obstruction from their tongue, mucus, vomit, etc. A modified lateral position is used and the following 6 principles are considered while choosing which variation of recovery position to use,

  1. The victim should be in as near a true lateral position as possible, with the head dependent to allow free drainage of fluid.

  2. The position should be stable.

  3. Avoid any pressure on the chest that impairs breathing.

  4. It should be possible to turn the victim on his or her side and to return to the back easily and safely, with concern for a possible cervical spine injury.

  5. Good observation of and access to the airway should be possible.

  6. The position itself should not cause injury to the victim.

Other options

Option A: Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing absent - In this situation, the patient is in cardiac arrest and requires immediate cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), not the recovery position. CPR involves chest compressions and rescue breaths to support circulation and respiration.

Option B: Unconsciousness with pulse present and breathing absent - In this case, the patient is experiencing respiratory arrest. Rescue breathing or bag-valve-mask ventilation should be initiated to support the patient's breathing. The recovery position is not indicated in this scenario.

Option D: Unconsciousness with pulse absent and breathing present - This option is not physiologically plausible, as the absence of a pulse implies a lack of circulation, and breathing cannot be present without circulation.

questions.text: A mother with polyhydramnios delivered a baby at term gestation. The baby chokes on the milk at every attempt, and on examination, the abdomen is distended and vesicular breath sounds are heard in bilateral lung fields. An attempt to pass a nasogastric tube fails. An X-ray is ordered and appears as shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms of choking and abdominal distention with a failure to pass a nasogastric tube and an X-ray showing NG tube in proximal esophagus and stomach distended with gas suggests the presence of a tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF).

A tracheoesophageal fistula is an abnormal fistula communication between the esophagus and trachea. Among the different types, Type C is the most common type. It consists of proximal esophageal atresia and distal TEF. With each breath, the air enters the distal esophagus and the stomach causing gastric distention which presents as abdominal distention. 

Inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube is a crucial pointer in the diagnosis of esophageal atresia. 

Tracheoesophageal fistula is associated with VACTERL (vertebral, anorectal, cardiac, tracheal, esophageal, renal, and limb) anomalies.

Other options:

Option A: Foreign body in the trachea will present with decreased air entry bilaterally in the lungs and stridor.

Option B: Gastric volvulus may also be associated with abdominal distension and difficulty in passing the NG tube into the stomach. However, in this case, the tube is seen stuck in the proximal esophagus itself making the diagnosis of TEF more likely.

Option D: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is usually left-sided and presents with respiratory distress. On examination, bowel sounds are heard in the chest field as abdominal contents herniate into the chest. There is a scaphoid abdomen rather than a distended abdomen as in this case.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheo-esophageal Fistula/Esophageal Atresia

Abbreviations:

  • EA: Esophageal atresia
  • TEF: Tracheoesophageal Fistula

questions.text: An air conditioner technician presents with diarrhea, high fever, chest pain, and dyspnea. Chest radiograph showed pleural effusion and patchy pulmonary infiltrates. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing the presence of gram-negative bacilli point toward the diagnosis of legionnaire's disease. Macrolides such as Azithromycin is the drug of choice for this condition.

Legionnaire’s disease is caused by Legionella pneumophila. They are found in lakes, streams, and other water bodies. Infection is mostly spread by inhalation of the bacteria from aerosols produced by contaminated air conditioners, humidifiers, nebulizers, etc.

It is mostly asymptomatic under the age of 55 years. Infection is usually severe in immunocompromised patients. It may present as a severe, rapidly progressive disease with high fever, chills, hypoxia, diarrhea, and delirium. On chest x-ray, patchy, often multilobar consolidation is seen. Pleural effusion may also occur. 

A milder form of a clinical syndrome known as Pontiac fever, which is usually self-limiting and only has mild symptoms of fever, myalgia, and headache.

Microscopy of the sputum samples shows numerous leucocytes without any organism. Gram staining of the sterile sites like pleural fluid and lung tissues show faint gram-negative bacilli. They require a counterstain of basic fuschin as safranin stains the bacteria very poorly. They are a group of fastidious, aerobic gram-negative bacteria. They can be grown on a buffered charcoal yeast extract (BCYE) agar.

Diagnosis is established with the help of direct fluorescent antibody tests and BCYE culture specimens. Urine antigen tests and molecular assays may also be used.

The below image shows the Direct Fluorescent Antibody Test.

As L. pneumophila is an intracellular pathogen, antibiotics that reach high intracellular concentrations must be used.

Macrolides and quinolones are the antibiotics of choice and are effective as monotherapy. Alternatively, agents like doxycycline may also be used. B-lactams, monobactams, and aminoglycosides are not considered to be effective. The total duration of therapy is 10-14 days for immunocompetent hosts and up to 3 weeks for immunosuppressed patients.

questions.text: At what age, normal level of visual acuity is attained?
questions.solution:
Full visual acuity is attained by the age of 6 years.

Important milestones in the visual development are:

  • At birth, there is no central fixation, and the eyes move randomly.
  • By the first month of life, fixation reflex starts developing and becomes established by 6 months.
  • By 3 months, binocular vision is established.
  • By 6 months, macular stereopsis and accommodation reflex are fully developed.
  • By 6 years of age, full visual acuity (6/6) is attained.

questions.text: Identify the given drain.
questions.solution:
The Romo Vac drain, depicted in the image, is a closed suction drain commonly used after mastectomy.

Drains are placed at surgical sites to freely collect the air or fluids that may accumulate. This enhances wound healing by preventing the formation of unnecessary cavities. Drains are prophylactic in elective surgeries and therapeutic in emergency surgeries. Drains can be -

  • Open - They are based on the principle of gravity 
  • Semi-open - Their action is based on capillary effect
  • Closed - They carry out their actions through suction

Suction drains are commonly used in chest, breast, abdominal, thyroid, and plastic surgeries. They remove intraperitoneal secretions, anastomotic leaks, and blood from hemorrhage at the surgical site. Romo Vac drain is a negative suction drain closed drain kept in the subcutaneous tissue. Romo Vac drain is indicated in modified radical mastectomy, subcutaneous swelling excision, and amputations. 

Special types of drains:

  • Chest drains (option A) are connected to an underwater seal to aid the exit of air from the pleural cavity. They are used in pneumothorax, pleural effusion, and hemothorax. 
  • After surgical exploration of the bile duct, the sphincter of Oddi goes into spasm. To facilitate drainage of bile, a T tube may be used. 

Drain insertion site care: The site of insertion of the drain is kept clean by drying and patting the drain insertion site with a clean towel after bath. The dressing is changed daily with folded gauze pieces placed below and above the drain site. 

Removal of drains: The catheter at the site is milked for residual collections. It is then clamped and the suture holding the catheter is cut. The tube is then gently pulled out and any clots at the perforation end are removed. The time of removal of drains for various conditions is given below. 

  • Drains used in surgeries like thyroidectomy are usually removed within 24 hours. Their main purpose is to cover postoperative bleeding. 
  • In a mastectomy, a drain is placed for 5 days to collect serous collections.
  • Drains used to cover the colorectal anastomoses are placed for 5-7 days.
  • Common bile duct T-tube drains are usually placed for 10 days.
  • Drains for infections are removed when the infection subsides or when the content of the drain is minimal.

After the drain is removed, a folded gauze is placed over the drain insertion area. The dressing can be removed after 24 hours. The patient may be given an antibiotic ointment to apply over the area for a week.

Other options:

Option A: The following image shows an underwater seal drain.

Option C: Nelaton drain/catheter is commonly used as an intermittent urinary catheter. Like other intermittent catheters, it is also attached temporarily for draining the bladder and then removed. 

Option D: A Penrose drain is a flexible, soft, latex tube that's used to drain fluid from a surgical site after surgery. It's a type of passive drain.

questions.text: A lady brings her son to you, complaining that the child walks in his sleep every night and always seems confused after waking up. He has no recollection of these events. What is the peak age group in which this disorder occurs?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of somnambulism (sleep walking), and the peak prevalence is between 4-8 years of age.

Somnambulism is a disorder of sleep arousal in which an individual arises from bed and carries out simple to complex motor activities without full consciousness. It occurs in the NREM phase of sleep. 

It is more commonly seen in children, with peak prevalence being between ages 4 to 8 years. It usually resolves after adolescence. It is rarely seen in adults, and has a familial pattern. It may occur secondary to other sleep disorders like sleep apnea. Sleep deprivation, interruption of slow-wave sleep, alcohol consumption, and stress can exacerbate the condition.

During an episode of sleepwalking, the individual may sit up, attempt to walk, or perform semi purposeful actions. They have a blank expression and are unresponsive to communication. Waking them up is possible only with great difficulty.

During the episode, patients can interact with the environment successfully (e.g., avoiding tripping over objects), but can also harm themselves (e.g., walking into the road). Legally, somnambulism is considered a form of automation, and hence doctrine of diminished responsibility applies. Hence, the person is not criminally responsible for his acts carried out during a fit.

 Management:

  • Reassurance
  • Maintaining patient safety during episodes
  • Avoiding sleep deprivation and alcohol consumption before going to bed
  • Antidepressants, relaxation techniques and hypnosis may also be helpful.

questions.text: Progestasert releases ______
questions.solution:
Progestasert releases 65 μg of progesterone/ day

Progestasert:

  • Progestasert is a T-shaped device carrying 38 mg of progesterone in silicon oil reservoir in the vertical stem. It releases 65 mcg of the hormone per day.
  • The hormone released in the uterus forms a thick plug of mucus at the cervical os which prevents penetration by the sperms and thus exerts an added contraceptive effect.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female with type 2 diabetes mellitus ingested an unknown quantity of metformin. On biochemical examination, her lactate levels are raised. What is the type of lactic acidosis encountered here?
questions.solution:
Metformin (biguanide) toxicity encountered here is a Type B lactic acidosis.

Lactic acidosis is defined as an increase in plasma lactate levels. The various types of L-lactic acidosis are:

  • Type A - This occurs secondary to poor tissue perfusion. The conditions include shock, cardiac failure, severe anemia, carbon monoxide, or cyanide toxicity.
  • Type B - This type of lactic acidosis occurs in aerobic disorders. It can occur secondary to malignancies, renal failure, hepatic failure, drugs like metformin, ethanol, ethylene glycol, and methanol, diabetes mellitus, seizures, Severe malaria/ cholera etc .

Note: A D-lactic acidosis is an unusual form of metabolic acidosis that occurs in patients with short bowel syndrome, post-jejunoileal bypass, or intestinal obstruction. This is due to the formation of D-lactate by gut bacteria.

questions.text: A patient presented to OPD with complaints of fever left eye lid swelling for the past two days as shown below . He had a mild flu-like illness a week ago but no history of trauma. There is no chemosis or any protrusion of the eyeball. Visual acuity, IOP, ocular motility, and pupils all were normal. Slit-lamp examination was unremarkable. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with eyelid swelling and fever following an infection without proptosis, loss of visual acuity, and ophthalmoplegia are suggestive of preseptal cellulitis/ Periorbital cellulitis.

Preseptal cellulitis is an infection of the subcutaneous tissues anterior to the orbital septum.
 
Etiological agents: Staph. aureus, Strep. pyogens
 
Mode of spread: Skin trauma, insect bites, acute hordeolum, dacryocystitis, conjunctivitis, sinusitis, Upper respiratory tract infection, and middle ear infection.
 
Presentation:
  1. Tender, firm, erythematous eye lid swelling
  2. Conjunctiva - usually no chemosis
  3. Proptosis - absent
  4. Ocular movements - normal
  5. Visual acuity - normal
  6. Systemic symptoms: fever, leucocytosis

Treatment: Antibiotics with systemic analgesics and warm compresses.

Complications: May spread and develop into orbital cellulitis, abscess formation, meningitis, and cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Option A:  Panophthalmitis would have an intense purulent inflammation of the whole eyeball that could be seen on a slit-lamp.

Option B: Orbital cellulitis refers to the acute infection of the contents of the orbit behind the orbital septum.It  presents with pain, lid edema, erythema, chemosis, and axial proptosis.Increased pain with movement of eyes and ophthalmoplegia (decreased ocular motility) is a classic symptoms. There is a rapid loss of vision is due to the involvement of the optic nerve.

Option D: Endophthalmitis is defined as the inflammation of the inner structures of the eyeball, i.e., uveal tissue and retina, associated with the pouring of exudates into the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber, and posterior chamber.

questions.text: Which among the following is used for the measurement of intraocular pressure (IOP) in a scarred cornea?
questions.solution:
Tonopen is used for measuring intraocular pressure (IOP) in a scarred cornea.

  • It is a hand-held electronic contact tonometer (a modified version of the older Mackay–Marg tonometer).
  • Besides portability, its main advantage is the ability to measure IOP reasonably accurately in eyes with distorted or edematous corneas and through a soft contact lens.

Measurement of IOP: Tonometry

Types:

  • Indentation tonometry: Reading depends on scleral rigidity, e.g., Schiotz tonometer  
  • Applanation tonometry: Based on the amount of force needed to flatten or applanate a known area of the cornea, Imbert–Fick principle

Applanation tonometry is of two types:
i) Fixed force: IOP is proportional to the area, e.g., Maklakov, Barraquer
ii) Fixed area and variable force: IOP is proportional to force. The most reliable is Goldmann.

  • Self-measurement: Rebound
  • Non-contact type: Pulse Air, Air-Puff
  • Irregular cornea: Tonopen, MacKay–Marg

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of metabolic alkalosis and respiratory alkalosis.

Since both the pH and bicarbonate are increased it is a case of metabolic alkalosis. Also, in the case of metabolic alkalosis, respiratory compensation includes a rise in PaCO2. But in this case, it is less than expected, which suggests concomitant respiratory alkalosis.

Finding the primary abnormality

pH = 7.50 Normal = (7.35 – 7.45) Increased
paCO2 = 36 Normal = (35 – 45) Normal
HCO3- = 30 Normal = (22 – 28) Increased

These values clearly suggest metabolic alkalosis.

Calculating the compensation

In metabolic alkalosis, the predicted PaCO2 after compensation should be [HCO3-] + 15.

So PaCO2 level after compensation should be [30] + [15] = 45 mmHg. However, PaCO2 levels are 36 mmHg, which is far lower than the expected value. This indicates that there is a component of respiratory alkalosis in this patient as well.

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic male patient came for a regular ophthalmic examination. He has no ocular complaints. A slit-lamp examination revealed the following finding in his right eye. It is also noted that these opacities do not settle down when the eye is immobile and moves with the vitreous during eye movements. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a diabetic, elderly male with unilateral numerous yellowish-white vitreous opacities that don’t sediment when the eye is immobile is suggestive of asteroid hyalosis.

Asteroid hyalosis is a common degenerative process in which calcium pyrophosphate particles collect within the vitreous gel. It is seen clinically as numerous tiny round yellow-white opacities of varying size and density. These move with the vitreous during eye movements but do not sediment inferiorly when the eye is immobile.

It occurs unilaterally (75%); patients are mostly asymptomatic. It is more common in elderly men. Associated with diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia.

Other options-

Option A:  Synchysis scintillans are vitreous opacities that occur as a consequence of chronic vitreous hemorrhage, often in a blind eye. They are composed of cholesterol derived from plasma cells or degraded products of erythrocytes. These vitreal opacities sediment in the lower part of the vitreous cavity due to gravity.

The below image shows Synchysis scintillans.

Option B: Muscae volitantes commonly referred to as ‘floaters’, is an ubiquitous entoptic phenomenon of fly-, cobweb- or thread-like condensations that are best seen against a pale background. It represents tiny embryological remnants in the vitreous gel. 

Image given below show floaters.

Option C: The vitreous opacities in amyloidosis are linear with footplate attachments to the retina and posterior surface of the lens and has a characteristic sheet-like (‘glass wool’) appearance.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old came at 32 weeks of gestation to the antenatal clinic. On per abdomen examination, the fundal height corresponds to 28 cm. Fetal biometry done previously was normal. On USG, abdominal circumference is < 10th percentile of that expected for the POG. Which of the following is the most likely cause?

POG - Period of gestation
questions.solution:
The history of presentation at 32 weeks and examination findings of fundal height less than the period of gestation with previous normal fetal biometry and abdominal circumference < 10th percentile of expected are suggestive of late-onset/ asymmetrical IUGR. The most likely cause of late IUGR is  Utero-placental insufficiency

Asymmetrical IUGR is late-onset and the most common cause is chronic placental insufficiency. 

The fundal height of the uterus corresponds to a period of gestation more than 24 weeks. Fundal height less than period of gestation raises the suspicion of Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR). Diagnosis of IUGR on USG is made by estimated fetal weight (EFW) < 10th percentile for that period of gestation (or) abdominal circumference (AC) < 10th percentile of expected for that period of gestation. 

Uteroplacental insufficiency can lead to less placental perfusion and therefore less fetal perfusion leading to decreased fetal urine production and thus can cause oligohydramnios. This patient will further need serial evaluation with USG biometry to look for symmetrical or asymmetrical IUGR and UA Doppler to look for fetal perfusion. 

Chromosomal abnormalities, TORCH infections will cause early-onset/ symmetrical IUGR which will be picked up early as 1st or 2nd trimester. 

Duodenal atresia, spinal bifida, tracheo-esophageal fistula are causes of polyhydramnios as they are all associated with open meninges or mucosal surfaces which exclude fluid and cause polyhydramnios which is not expected in case of IUGR.

questions.text: A patient presents with dyspnea and distended neck veins that increase on inspiration. There is no murmur. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient presenting with dyspnea and Kussmauls signs as evidenced by the distended neck veins that increase on inspiration, likely has underlying constrictive pericarditis.

Constrictive pericarditis: It is a condition where a thickened, fibrotic, and often calcified pericardium restricts the diastolic filling of the heart.

In developing countries, infectious etiologies like tuberculosis or viral infections are the most common cause of this condition. Cardiac surgery and radiation therapy are also common causes. Other causes include connective tissue disease, uremia, neoplasm, or idiopathic.

Clinically the patients may present with dyspnea, orthopnea, fatigue, ascites. On examination neck veins may be distended and will show a positive Kussmauls sign. On auscultation, heart sound smay be distant and a pericardial knock at the cardiac apex may be heard. This occurs due to the abrubt cessation of ventricular filling.

JVP findings - There is a rapid 'x' and 'y' descent. The rapid 'y' descent is more prominent and reflects rapid early ventricular diastolic filling. This occurs due to the constricting pericardium, increasing the atrial pressures.

Diagnosis: Diagnosis is difficult and is confirmed by multiple investigations

  • Hallmark findings of pericardial constriction are pericardial thickening, calcification, and abnormal ventricular diastolic function.
  • The X-ray can be normal or there may be non-specific cardiac enlargement, calcification, and roughened cardiac outline.
  • CT and MRI are more sensitive investigations.

Constrictive pericarditis will have prominent y descent, prominent x descent, and Kussmaul's sign. Normally, the venous pressure should fall by at least 3 mmHg with inspiration. Kussmaul’s sign is defined by either a rise or a lack of fall of the JVP with inspiration.

 

Other options:

Option B: Aortic regurgitation would present with a diastolic murmur.

Option C: Tricuspid stenosis may also present similarly with congestive hepatomegaly, and venous distention, however, in this patient the absence of a murmur makes the diagnosis unlikely. Tricuspid stenosis will have prolonged y wave on JVP.

Option D: Pulmonary arterial hypertension would present with a prominent jugular "a" wave, palpable left parasternal lift, and loud S2 which are not seen in this patient.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the Gaisböck syndrome?
questions.solution:
Patients with Gaisböck syndrome do not have hypotension, but rather present with hypertension.

Gaisböck syndrome is a stress polycythemia where affected individuals are usually hypertensive, obese, and anxious. They have a high hematocrit, low plasma volume, normal leukocyte counts, and no splenomegaly (differentiating them from polycythemia vera).

The plasma volume is therefore used to differentiate relative polycythemia where there is a reduction in plasma volume from absolute polycythemia, which is due to an absolute increase in red cell mass.

Polycythemia denotes an abnormally high red cell count, usually with a corresponding increase in the hemoglobin level (> 16 ±2 g/dL). It is 2 types:

Causes of relative polycythemia include:

  • Dehydration - deprivation of water, prolonged vomiting or diarrhea, excessive use of diuretics
  • Gaisböck syndrome 

Causes of absolute polycythemia include:

  • Primary - intrinsic abnormality of hematopoietic precursors 
    • Polycythemia vera
    • Inherited erythropoietin receptor mutations
  • Secondary - red cell progenitors responding to increased levels of erythropoietin
    • Compensatory due to cyanotic heart and lung disease, high altitude
    • Paraneoplastic erythropoietin-secreting tumors

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy fell from the bed and developed swelling in the nose and difficulty in breathing. Examination revealed smooth rounded swellings on either side of the septum, through both the nares. On palpation, it was soft and fluctuant. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of a septal hematoma. The most appropriate next step in management would be incision and drainage of the hematoma. 

Septal hematoma is caused due to collection of blood in between the perichondrium or periosteum and the cartilage of the nasal septum. It may be caused due to trauma, septal surgery, or spontaneously as in bleeding disorders.

Clinically, patients may present with bilateral nasal obstruction, pain, pressure over the nasal bridge, or a frontal headache. On examination, bilateral hematomas will be seen as purplish or reddish smooth swelling on either side of the septum. Palpation will reveal a soft, fluctuant swelling.

All septal hematomas must be drained to prevent the formation of septal abscess or organization of the hematoma by fibrosis leading to a permanently thickened septum. Drainage of the hematoma should be done either through aspiration with a wide gauge needle or through an incision made over the mucosa at the point of greatest fluctuation. It must be followed by nasal packing. Patients should thereafter be started on systemic antibiotics.

Given below are a clinical image and a illustrated image of septal hematoma.

Related Pearl: Septal Haematoma

  • Septal hematoma is a collection of blood under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasal septum
  • Causes: Trauma, septal surgery and bleeding disorders
  • Clinical features: Bilateral nasal obstruction (most common presenting feature), frontal headache
  • Treatment:
    • Aspiration of small hematomas
    • Incision and drainage of large hematomas followed by nasal packing
    • Systemic antibiotics to prevent abscess formation
  • Complications: Septal abscess, depression of dorsum, permanently thickened septum

questions.text: In surgical management of pneumothorax, one of the objectives is to make the visceral pleura adherent to the parietal pleura to contain subsequent leaks and prevent complete lung collapse. Pleural adhesion cannot be achieved in which of the following ways?
questions.solution:
Pleural adhesion cannot be achieved by pleural diathermy.

Diathermy is a surgical method that uses electrical energy in a controlled manner, causing targeted thermal damage to tissues.

Surgery for pneumothorax can be performed by video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) or as an open procedure (thoracotomy). One of the objectives is to make the visceral pleura adherent to the parietal pleura to contain subsequent leaks and prevent complete lung collapse.

Pleural adhesion is achieved in one of three ways:

  • Pleurectomy: systematically stripping the parietal pleura from the chest wall.
  • Pleural abrasion: a scourer is used to scrape off the slick surface of the parietal pleura.
  • Chemical pleurodesis: usually talc is used and is insufflated into the chest cavity.

questions.text: Identify step 3 in the given cataract surgery procedure.
questions.solution:
The picture illustrates extracapsular cataract extraction by the phacoemulsification method. Step 3 indicates hydrodissection.

Hydrodissection is the process of separating the capsule from the nucleus and cortex by injecting fluid between the two. This step is used in all extracapsular cataract extraction procedures and is mandatory in phacoemulsification and manual small incision cataract surgeries.

The steps involved in the cataract surgery are: 

  • Step 1 - small clear corneal incision 
  • Step 2 - continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis
  • Step 3 - hydrodissection, which also facilitates rotation and manipulation of the nucleus during emulsification of the lens
  • Step 4 - hydro delineation is done in some cases. This is done by injecting fluid between the nucleus and epinuclear lens substance. It aids in the separation of the cortex from the nucleus
  • Steps 5 and 6 - indicate the divide and conquer technique for the removal of the nucleus after phacoemulsification
  • Step 7 - removal of the cortical lens matter using an irrigation-aspiration technique
  • Step 8 - implantation of a foldable lens

questions.text: A 57 year old male patient who has been diagnosed with aggressive pancreatic cancer presents with intractable abdominal pain unresponsive to opioids. The anesthetist decides to opt for a regional block. Which of the following would he choose?
questions.solution:
The block he would choose in the case of pancreatic cancer is celiac plexus block.

The celiac plexus block is indicated in patients with pain arising from the abdominal viscera, specifically intraabdominal cancers. 

The celiac ganglia are generally clustered at the level of the body of the L1 vertebra, posterior to the inferior vena cava on the right and lateral to the aorta on the left. It is posterior to the pancreas. 

The patient is placed in a prone position and 15-20 ml of local anesthetic is injected under fluoroscopic, CT, or ultrasound guidance. The needed should be inserted 7-8cm from the midline at the inferior edge of the spinous process of L1. 

The approaches that can be taken for this block include the posterior retrocrural approach, posterior anterocrural approach, posterior transaortic approach, an anterior approach. 

The most common complication is postural hypotension. This occurs due to blocking of visceral sympathetic innervation which results in vasodilation. To prevent this, the patient should be adequately hydrated intravenously. 

Other options: 

Option A: The stellate block is indicated in patients with head, neck, arm, and upper chest pain. 

Option B: The lumbar sympathetic block is indicated in painful conditions involving the pelvis and lower extremities like a peripheral vascular disease. 

Option D: The superior hypogastric plexus block is indicated in pelvic pain that is unresponsive to lumbar or caudal epidural blocks. It is used in patients with cancer of the pelvic organs or non-cancer pelvic pain.

questions.text: A  22 year old girl enquires if there are any surgical options for the correction of her myopia. She does not wish to wear her glasses anymore, nor does she wish to switch to contact lenses. What is the minimum time frame for which her refractive error has to be stable before laser assisted in-situ keratomileusis (LASIK) can be considered for her?
questions.solution:
The patient's refractive error has to be stable for a minimum period of atleast 1 year before undergoing laser assisted in-situ keratomileusis. (LASIK)

Laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis (LASIK) is performed using excimer laser. It is the surgery of choice for myopia. 

Excimer laser beam reshapes the cornea by ablating the superficial stroma to a predetermined extent after lifting a flap of the cornea with a sharp
microkeratome. 

Steps: microkeratome cut, laser photoablation with flap lifted, flap repositioning.

Patient selection criteria:

  • In individuals aged 21 years and above.
  • In individuals who have a stable refractive error for atleast 1 year.
  • In individuals who have had unsatisfactory results with non-surgical treatment.
  • In individuals in whom corneal-thinning disorders such as keratoconus have been ruled out.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female patient presented with electric shock-like sensations that go down her legs, from two days. She has a history of sensory loss over her face that resolved without treatment a few months back. One year ago, she had decreased visual acuity for one day which then resolved. Her T2-weighted MRI is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is multiple sclerosis (MS). 

The MRI given depicts Dawson's fingers which are areas of perivenous demyelination that are seen as lesions that are perpendicular to the ventricle. They appear as hyperintense areas on the T2-weighted images.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease characterized by inflammation, multiple demyelinating plaques, and relapsing and remitting symptoms. It occurs due to infiltration of the white matter by T cells and macrophages leading to axonal damage and neurodegeneration. It presents abruptly or insidiously with variable intensity of symptoms depending on the location. 

The most common symptoms experienced are as follows:

  1. Sensory symptoms:
    1. Paresthesia, pins and needles sensations, hypoesthesia
    2. Horizontal cut-off on limbs for sensory involvement suggests lesions at the level of the spinal cord 
    3. Pain
  2. Optic neuritis:
    1. Reduced visual acuity, color perception, dimness in the central visual field, unilaterally or bilaterally.
    2. Periorbital pain
    3. Funduscopy: optic disc swelling, pallor
  3. Weakness of limbs
    1. Loss of strength, speed, dexterity
    2. Gait disturbance
    3. Upper motor neuron weakness
    4. Pyramidal signs: spasticity, hyperreflexia
    5. Babinski sign positive
  4. Facial weakness 
  5. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia - bilaterally
  6. Ataxia, vertigo

Paroxysmal symptoms may occur, characterized by short duration and high-frequency occurrence per day. These can manifest as:

  • Lhermitte's sign - electric shock-like sensations that go down legs or back on neck flexion
  • Uthoff symptom -neurological symptoms produced by elevated core body temperature
  • Tonic seizures and dysarthria
  • Trigeminal neuralgia, and facial myokymia 
  • Bladder dysfunction as detrusor hyperreflexia or detrusor sphincter dyssynergia
  • Fatigue

MS can have three different clinical courses: 

  1. Relapsing or bout onset (90%) of cases. Here, there is complete recovery between episodes. As the disease progresses, the recovery may not be complete. 
  2. Secondary progressive MS starts as relapsing MS but then experiences decreased function as a result of the attacks.
  3. Primary progressive MS (10% of the cases) has a consistent decline in function from disease onset. They do not have discrete episodes. 

Diagnosis of MS requires at least two or more episodes of symptoms and two or more signs that show the involvement of noncontiguous white matter tracks. The symptoms must last for at least one day and must be separated chronologically by one month. 

MRI demonstrates increased vascular permeability and multifocal hyperintense lesions. Dawson's fingers may be present. The cerebrospinal fluid examination will show mononuclear cell pleocytosis and increased IgG. 

Other options: 

Option A - Thalamic stroke is usually unilateral and is characterized by hemi-sensory disturbance throughout the body. 

Option C - Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by extreme episodic pain affecting the area of the face supplied by the trigeminal nerve except for the ophthalmic division. It is of sudden onset and short duration, lasting up to a few minutes. 

Option D - Neuromyelitis optical (NMO) is characterized by recurrent optic neuritis and transverse myelitis. It is similar in presentation to MS except that NMO is severe, bilateral, and can cause severe visual loss. Myelitis usually involves three or more contiguous vertebral segments. NMO does not have progressive symptoms in contrast to MS.
