questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with painless hematuria. He is diagnosed with non-invasive bladder cancer. After resection, he was categorised into a high-risk category. What is the next best step in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
The next step in this patient with a high-risk category of non-muscle-invasive bladder cancer(NMIBC) is intravesical administration of BCG.

Clinical features of bladder carcinoma include:

  • Painless gross haematuria - Most common symptom and is indicative of a bladder carcinoma until proven otherwise
  • Urinary retention
  • Constant pelvic pain
  • Increased urinary frequency
  • Discomfort while urinating
  • If there is nerve involvement, pain is referred to the suprapubic region, groins, perineum, and thighs.

 Management of bladder cancer:

Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer: The aim of managing patients with NMIBC is to reduce the risk of tumour recurrence and progression to muscle-invasive bladder cancer(MIBC). The initial management consists of transurethral resection of bladder tumours(TURBT). Following this patients are stratified according to the risk of recurrence and progression.

  • Highest risk tumours: Radical cystectomy or intravesical bacillus Calmette–Guérin (BCG)
  • Intermediate-risk tumours: a 6-week course of intravesical mitomycin C.
  • Low-risk tumours regular cystoscopic surveillance alone.

Muscle invasive bladder cancer:

  • Radical cystectomy along with urinary diversion procedure and lymph node dissection +/- neoadjuvant chemotherapy.
  • Systemic chemotherapy with a combination of drugs – cisplatin, methotrexate, doxorubicin, and vinblastine (M-VAC) or cisplatin along with gemcitabine is given before radical cystectomy(neoadjuvant).
  • Radical beam external radiotherapy for very elderly or unfit patients who are unsuitable for radical cystectomy.

The most important prognostic factor in bladder carcinoma is the depth of invasion.

questions.text: A 33-year-old lady presents with complaints of ear pain associated with impaired hearing. Further evaluation by otoscopy reveals a dull and lustreless tympanic membrane with prominent lateral process of the malleus. Which of the following curves will be obtained if she undergoes tympanometry?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical case, otoscopy findings of a dull and lustreless tympanic membrane with prominent lateral process of the malleus, are highly suggestive of a retracted tympanic membrane. On Tympanometry, a Type C tympanogram (Curve 1) with normal compliance and negative pressure is seen in the case of a retracted tympanic membrane.

Features of retracted TM:

  • TM is dull and lustreless.
  • The cone of light is absent or interrupted.
  • The handle of the malleus appears foreshortened.
  • The lateral process of the malleus becomes more prominent.
  • Anterior and posterior malleal folds become sickle-shaped.

Tympanometry: It is used in evaluating the status of the middle ear and the functioning of the eustachian tube. Results of tympanometry are plotted in the form of a tympanogram with:

  • Compliance on the Y axis (ease of mobility of TM)
  • Middle ear pressure on the X axis (regulated by eustachian tube)

Principle: When a sound wave strikes the tympanic membrane, some of the sound energy is absorbed while the rest is reflected. A stiffer tympanic membrane would reflect more sound energy than a compliant one.

Tympanometry has also been used to evaluate the function of the eustachian tube in cases of intact or perforated tympanic membrane. A pressure of —200 or +200 mm H2O is created in the middle ear and the person is asked to swallow 5 times in 20 seconds. The ability to equilibrate the pressure indicates normal tubal function. It is also used in evaluating the patency of the grommet inserted in the tympanic membrane for treating serous otitis media.

Curve 4- Type Ad curve. High compliance at or near ambient pressure. Seen in ossicular discontinuity or thin and lax tympanic membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about gamma knife?

choices.text: It is used for the treatment of tuberculoma
It can be performed anywhere in the body

questions.solution:
Gamma knife is a type of stereotactic radiotherapy or surgery (SRS) which is a reasonable alternative for people who refuse or cannot tolerate surgery. Here, beams are modified and focused only to concentrate on the tumor and have little effect on surrounding tissue. SRS can be done by using: 

  • X-knife using a linear accelerator (LINAC)
  • Gamma-knife using Cobalt 60 as source (Option B)
  • CyberKnife - image-guided linear accelerator using real-time image guidance to deliver radiation from multiple angles.

In gamma knife, the patient wears a specialized helmet called Leksell’s frame that is surgically fixed to the skull. Gamma knife aims gamma radiation through a target point in the patient’s brain. An ablative dose of radiation is thereby sent through the tumour in one treatment session while surrounding brain tissues are relatively spared. 

The classic indications of cobalt-based stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) and gamma knife are:

  • Arterio-venous malformation
  • Acoustic schwannoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Meningioma
  • Trigeminal neuralgia

Other options:

Option D: Helmet or frame is needed to perform gamma knife therapies. So, they are limited to brain pathology. Cyberknife uses X-ray (LINAC), which can be performed anywhere in the body with the help of a robotic arm.

His temperature on admission was 38.5 °C. Examination revealed a pan-systolic murmur which was loudest at the left sternal edge. Three sets of blood cultures were taken. questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario the patient is having malaise and fever and on examination pan-systolic murmur is heard which is suggestive of infective endocarditis. Staphylococcus aureus is most likely to be positive in cultures as it is the most common cause of infective endocarditis in IV drug abusers. Infective endocarditis is a microbial infection of the heart valves or the mural endocardium that leads to the formation of vegetations composed of thrombotic debris and organisms, often associated with the destruction of the underlying cardiac tissue.

Clinical features include subungual splinter haemorrhages, Osler nodes, Janeway lesions, and Roth spots. 

The image below shows Osler nodes which are painful raised violaceous lesions commonly affecting the fingers, toes, and feet. It is immunologically mediated.

questions.text: Schneider’s first-rank symptoms of schizophrenia include all of the following except ________
questions.solution:
Ambivalence is not a first-rank symptom of schizophrenia. It is one of the 4A’s of schizophrenia as described by Bleuler.

The first rank symptoms of schizophrenia described by Kurt Schneider include :

1. Hallucination:

  • Audible thoughts - auditory hallucinations of a person’s voice being spoken aloud.
  • Voices arguing or discussing - auditory hallucinations of two or more voices arguing or discussing, usually about the person experiencing the hallucination.
  • Voices commenting on the patient’s actions - auditory hallucinations commenting on a person’s behavior or actions.

2. Thought Phenomenon : 

  • Thought withdrawal -  thoughts being actively removed from a person’s mind.
  • Thought insertion - thoughts inserted into a person’s mind by some external agent.
  • Thought broadcasting - the sense that a person’s thoughts are experienced by others - the thoughts are made audible or may be experienced by others through telepathy.

3. Made Phenomenon:

  • Made affect - feelings are imposed on that person by an external agent.
  • Made impulses or drives - an impulse for action is imposed on a person by some external agent.
  • Made volitional acts - a person’s actions are controlled by an external agent; the person is a passive participant in the action.

4. Delusional perception - the person attaches an abnormal significance/meaning to a normal perception, which leads to delusional interpretation.

5. Somatic passivity - tactile or visceral hallucinations that are thought to be imposed on a person's body by some external agent.

These symptoms are not specific for schizophrenia and may also be present in other psychiatric disorders.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents with erythematous painful lesions on the trunk and face, joint pain, and glove and stocking pattern of anesthesia. Which of the following investigations is used for the diagnosis of this condition?
  1. Nerve examination
  2. Skin biopsy
  3. Slit skin smear
  4. Mantoux test
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points to a case of leprosy. The diagnosis of this condition requires nerve examination, skin biopsy, and a slit skin smear (option B- 1, 2, 3).

Leprosy is a chronic granulomatous condition caused by Mycobacterium leprae. It affects the skin, cutaneous and peripheral nerves, and mucous membranes. The most commonly affected peripheral nerves are the posterior tibial nerve, followed by the ulnar, median, and lateral popliteal nerves. The most commonly involved cranial nerve is the facial nerve. 

Leprosy has a long incubation period, usually ranging from 2 to 12 years. It commonly presents as an area of numbness on the skin or a visible skin lesion which could be a hypopigmented or erythematous macule. Lesions usually involve the face, extensor aspect of the limbs, trunks, and buttocks. The lesions have impaired nerve function and poor hair growth. The patients may also present with burns or ulcers of the anesthetic limb.

Classification systems of leprosy: 

  • Ridley-Jopling classification:
    • Tuberculoid (TT)
    • Borderline tubercular (BT)
    • Borderline (BB)
    • Borderline lepromatous (BL)
    • Lepromatous (LL)
  • WHO classification:
    • Paucibacillary
    • Multibacillary

Cardinal signs for the diagnosis of leprosy:

  • Characteristic skin lesions- hypopigmented or erythematous lesions with definite impairment of sensation.
  • Peripheral nerve involvement- thickening of the nerve with sensory impairment. Nerve tenderness can also be seen.
  • Detection of acid-fast bacilli in slit-skin smear, skin biopsy, or positive biopsy PCR.

The presence of two of the three signs can establish the diagnosis of leprosy. Other tests done for diagnosis of leprosy include nerve biopsy in pure neural leprosy and PGL-1 antibody in cases with low bacterial load.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the marked incision shown below?

questions.solution:
The incision marked is the Pfannenstiel incision where the rectus muscles are not transected.

Pfannenstiel incision is the most common incision made in caesarean delivery.It follows Langer lines of skin tension. A transverse and slightly curvilinear incision is made in the skin and subcutaneous tissue 3 cm above the superior border of the pubic symphysis. This is stretched laterally for 12-15 cm to accommodate the delivery of the fetus. Following this, the rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain entry to the peritoneum.

The Maylard incision (the unmarked incision in the image) differs mainly from the Pfannenstiel in that the bellies of the rectus abdominis muscles are transected horizontally to widen the operating space.

questions.text: A young male who is a professional trumpet blower presented with a swelling on the left side of the neck. On examination, there is a gurgling sound when compressing the swelling. As the X-ray neck was inconclusive a CT neck was taken which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT image along with the examination finding of Bryce sign is suggestive of laryngocoele.

Laryngocoele:

  • Air-filled cavity within the larynx developing in the saccule.
  • The patient presents with a neck swelling that is soft and compressible.
  • Bryce sign: on compressing the swelling, there is a gurgling sound.

It is seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to raised transglottic air pressure. It presents with hoarseness, cough, and if large, causes obstruction of the airway.

Types of laryngocoele are:

  • Internal - confined within the larynx and presents as distension of false cord and aryepiglottic fold.
  • External - the distended saccule herniates through the thyroid membrane and presents in the neck. It presents as a reducible swelling in the neck, increasing in size on coughing or performing Valsalva manoeuvres.
  • Mixed - both external and internal compounds are seen

Diagnosis is done by indirect laryngoscopy, soft tissue AP and lateral views of the neck x-ray with Valsalva. CT scan helps to find out the extent of the lesion. External type is managed by surgical excision through an external neck incision. Internal type is managed by marsupialization and endoscopic carbon dioxide laser resection.

Other options:

Option A: Zenker diverticulum or pharyngeal pouch is a pulsion-pseudodiverticulum and results from herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian triangle (or dehiscence of Killian). Killian's triangle is an area of muscular weakness between the transverse fibers of the cricopharyngeus and the oblique fibers of the thyropharyngeus.

Option C: A tracheoesophageal fistula is an abnormal fistula communication between the Esophagus and Trachea. Type C lesion is associated with proximal esophageal atresia and distal TEF, the proximal blind pouch ends approximately at the distance of one or two vertebral bodies from the distal TEF.

Option D: A tonsillar cyst is due to blockage of a tonsillar crypt and appears as a yellowish swelling over the tonsil. Very often it is symptomless. It can be easily drained.

questions.text:
Identify the shunt depicted in the image below.

[IVC-Inferior vena cava, PV-Portal vein, SV-Splenic vein, LRV-Left renal vein]
questions.solution:
The image shows Warren's shunt (distal lienorenal shunt). This is the only selective shunt out of the four options given hence it has the least risk of hepatic encephalopathy. 

TIPS(Transjugular Intravenous Porto Systemic shunt):

The main indication of TIPS is variceal bleeds not responding to medical or endoscopic treatment and intractable ascites.

The shunts are inserted under local anesthesia, analgesia, and sedation, using fluoroscopic guidance and ultrasonography. A guidewire is inserted via the internal jugular vein and superior vena cava into a hepatic vein and through the hepatic parenchyma into a branch of the portal vein.

The major complication of this technique is the perforation of the liver capsule and the main contraindication to TIPSS is portal vein occlusion.

Portal hypertension is defined by a portal pressure >5 mmHg.

Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) is a treatment option whereby a percutaneous connection is created within the liver, between the portal and systemic circulations, to reduce portal pressure in patients with complications related to portal hypertension.

Complications of TIPS procedure:

  • Intraoperative complications- capsular hemorrhage
  • Early complication- hepatic encephalopathy
  • Late complication- recurrent variceal bleed
  • Delayed complication- total shunt occlusion

Shunts for portal hypertension:

  • Non-selective shunt- bowel and splenic blood is shunted
    • Linton shunt (proximal lienorenal shunt with splenectomy)
    • ECK fistula (portocaval shunt)
    • Mitra shunt (splenorenal shunt)
  • Selective shunt- only splenic blood is shunted
    • Warren shunt (distal lienorenal shunt)
    • Inokuchi shunt

  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Coronary artery disease
  • Cardiomyopathies
  • Chronic kidney disease

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient with a history of chronic smoking presented with Intermittent calf pain. Angiography shows an inverted tree-like appearance of arteries of both lower limbs. All of the following clinical features can be seen in this patient except:
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the given scenario is thromboangiitis obliterans / Buerger disease. Acrocyanosis has no association with TAO.

Acrocyanosis is persistent, painless cyanosis seen in fingers and often in legs with paraesthesia and chilblains affecting young females.

Buerger's disease is a progressive nonatherosclerotic segmental inflammatory disease that most often affects small- and medium-sized arteries, veins, and nerves of the lower extremities. It is characterized by occlusive disease of small- and medium-sized arteries, thrombophlebitis of the superficial or deep veins, and Raynaud’s syndrome.

Clinical features:

  • Common in male smokers below 40 years of age group
  • Intermittent claudication in foot and calf progressing to rest pain, ulceration, gangrene.
  • Recurrent migratory superficial thrombophlebitis.
  • Absent/feeble pulses distal to proximal; dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, popliteal, femoral arteries.
  • May present as Raynaud’s phenomenon.
  • Raynaud's phenomenon is episodic vasospasm. It leads to a sequence of clinical features called Raynaud’s syndrome comprising of local syncope, local asphyxia, and local recovery.

Investigations:

  • Arterial doppler and duplex scan (doppler + B-mode U/S).
  • Transfemoral retrograde angiogram through Seldinger technique shows blockage—sites, extent, and severity
    • The corkscrew appearance of the vessel is due to dilatation of vasa vasorum.
    • Inverted tree/spider leg collaterals.

    • Distal runoff is the amount of dye filling in the main vessel distal to the obstruction through collaterals. If the distal run-off is good then ischemia is compensated. If the distal run-off is poor then ischemia is decompensated.

Treatment:

  • Cessation of smoking is the definitive management. 
  • Drugs to improve circulation include
    • Pentoxifylline
    • Aspirin
    • Clopidogrel
    • Statins 
    • Cilostazol- Phosphodiesterase inhibitor is ideally used to improve circulation in the collaterals formed.
    • Vasodilators and anticoagulants have no role in the treatment.
  • Care of limb with Buerger’s exercise and positioning 
  • Surgical management may include lumbar sympathectomy and amputation according to the presenting features.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with severe pancreatitis. The next day he develops sudden onset breathlessness and severe hypoxia. Below is the chest X-ray obtained. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of severe pancreatitis and the chest X-ray findings of B/L diffuse alveolar opacities are suggestive of ARDS.

Acute respiratory distress syndrome is a clinical syndrome characterized by acute onset, severe dyspnea, tachypnea, hypoxemia, and pulmonary infiltrates leading to respiratory failure. Etiological factors can be divided into direct and indirect causes of lung injury as follows:

Direct lung injury-

  • Pneumonia
  • Aspiration of gastric contents
  • Near drowning
  • Toxic inhalation injury
  • Pulmonary contusion
  • COVID-19

Indirect lung injury-

  • Sepsis
  • Severe trauma like burns, flail chest, head trauma, multiple bone fractures
  • Transfusions
  • Drug overdose
  • Multiple transfusions
  • Pancreatitis
  • Drug overdose

There are three stages in the development of ARDS:

Exudative phase: Occurs for the first 7 days of the illness. The alveolar-capillary endothelial cells and type I pneumocytes are injured, with a breach in the tight alveolar barrier. Proinflammatory cytokines like IL-8, IL-1, TNF-α, and LT-B4 lead to the recruitment of neutrophils and the development of a hyaline membrane in the alveoli.

Proliferative phase: Occurs from day 7-21. Recovery from mechanical ventilation is seen in most patients. Some patients may develop pulmonary fibrosis in this stage. Histological recovery is seen in this phase with a shift to lymphocyte predominant infiltrates. Type II pneumocytes proliferate and secrete surfactant with subsequent differentiation to Type I pneumocytes.

Fibrotic phase: Is associated with increased mortality. Extensive alveolar duct and interstitial fibrosis are seen.

Chest X-ray features in ARDS:

Chest x-ray features usually develop 12-24 hours after initial lung insult as a result of proteinaceous interstitial edema. Within one week, hyaline membrane occurs due to type 1 pneumocyte damage. There are diffuse bilateral coalescent opacities consistent with pulmonary edema. 

Severity classification of ARDS:

Mild: 200 mmHg < Pao2/Fio2 ≤ 300 mmHg
Moderate: 100 mmHg < Pao2/Fio2 ≤ 200 mmHg
Severe: Pao2/Fio2 ≤ 100 mmHg

Management includes :

  • Mechanical ventilation with low tidal volume and high-PEEP.
  • Prone ventillation
  • Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation
  • Early neuromuscular blockade

questions.text: A 24-year-old lady presented with vomiting, abdominal distention, and postprandial epigastric pain.  A barium meal follow-through of the patient is given below. Which of the given statements regarding the patient's likely condition is false?

choices.text: Third part of the duodenum is compressed
Angle between superior mesenteric artery and aorta is more obtuse (>100)
This condition is also called as Wilkie’s syndrome

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the barium follow-through demonstrating dilation of the duodenum with an abrupt cut-off at its third part, coinciding with the line of the superior mesenteric artery is suggestive of superior mesenteric artery (SMA) syndrome/Wilkie syndrome. In this condition, the angle between the superior mesenteric artery and the aorta is more acute (<20 degrees).

Wilkie syndrome is usually seen in young women who are physically weak. It is a rare condition in which the SMA compresses the third portion of the duodenum. The normal aortomesenteric angle is between 38-65 degrees. This is reduced to 20 degrees (according to some texts it is 15.2 degrees and in some, it is 18 degrees) in SMA syndrome. The SMA obstructs the third part of the duodenum by compressing it against fixed retroperitoneal structures. 

Symptoms include epigastric pain which is episodic and postprandial in nature, nausea, vomiting, abdominal distention, and weight loss.

SMA syndrome is associated with:

  • Rapid childhood growth
  • Profound weight loss
  • Abdominal surgery
  • Inflammatory diseases of the abdomen
  • Immobilization in a cast that increases lordosis and accentuates the angle of the SMA with the aorta (cast syndrome)

Upper gastrointestinal barium studies are used for diagnosis. CT is also useful in some cases.

Treatment includes:

  • Medical therapy- frequent small feedings, lying on prone or left side postprandially, weight gain, or removal of a body cast improves symptoms.
  • Laparoscopic lysis of the ligament of Treitz is beneficial in a few cases.
  • The following surgical procedures can be done- duodenojejunostomy, gastrojejunostomy, and duodenal derotation (Strong procedure).

The given image shows compressed angle between SMA and the abdominal aorta in CT angiography.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is being evaluated for the following deformity of his left elbow. Three years ago, he suffered a fracture of his left humerus following a fall on his outstretched hand. Which of the following types does the fracture leading to this complication belong to, as per the Salter-Harris classification?
questions.solution:
The image shows the cubitus valgus deformity of the left elbow, which is usually a complication of lateral condyle fracture of the humerus. It belongs to type IV of the Salter-Harris classification.

Fracture of the lateral condyle of the humerus is most likely to be seen in a child with a fall on an outstretched hand in a varus position. 

A large fragment of bone including the lateral condyle breaks off and is pulled away by the attached wrist extensors. The normal 3-point bony relationship at the elbow is lost. It is a Salter-Harris type IV injury. 

These fractures are managed surgically (fracture of necessity) with open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) using either screws or K-wire. 

Non-union is commonly seen in these fractures. If left untreated, the lateral growth plate fails to grow, while the medial one continues to grow, resulting in a cubitus valgus deformity. 

Related Pearl: Types of Salter–Harris fractures- Mnemonic

There are nine types of Salter-Harris fractures. Among these, types I to V are more common.

The mnemonic "SALTER" can be used to help remember the first five types.

Type I S = Slip/straight across Transverse fracture through the growth plate
Type II A = Away The fracture lies away from the joint. A fracture through the growth plate and the metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis
Type III L = Lower The fracture is below the physis in the epiphysis.
Type IV TE = Through Everything  A fracture through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis
Type V R = Rammed (crushed)  A compression fracture of the growth plate

Rarer types VI to IX have been added subsequently.

  • Type VI - Injury to the perichondral structures
  • Type VII - Isolated injury to the epiphyseal plate
  • Type VIII - Isolated injury to the metaphysis, with a potential injury related to endochondral ossification
  • Type IX - Injury to the periosteum that may interfere with membranous growth

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with watery diarrhea for the past few weeks that did not respond to medication along with frequent epigastric pain, bloating, and indigestion. Stool culture was negative but he was found to have microcytic hypochromic anemia and his serum K+ was 2.9 mmol/L. Upper GI endoscopy was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes watery diarrhea, hypokalemia (serum K+<3.5 mM), and symptoms of achlorhydria (bloating, indigestion, iron deficiency) which suggests the diagnosis of WDHA syndrome caused by VIPoma.

VIPoma is pancreatic endocrine neoplasia. The tumor secretes vasoactive intestinal peptides which are responsible for the secretory watery diarrhea and other symptoms mentioned above. While suspecting a case of VIPoma it is essential to conduct a VIP assay so as to confirm the presence of other tumors of neural crest origin such as neuroblastoma or pheochromocytoma. 

Diagnosis can be made by the demonstration of an elevated plasma VIP level and the history of large-volume diarrhea.

Other options:

questions.text: You are on duty in the gastroenterology department as a second-year resident, evaluating patients for upper and lower gastrointestinal lesions. What will be your diagnosis of the following images?

A- Mallory Weiss tear, B- Barrett's esophagus
A- Crohn’s Disease, B- Ulcerative Colitis
A- Ulcerative Colitis, B- Crohn’s Disease

questions.solution:
Image A shows ulcerative colitis and image B shows Crohn's disease.

The given image A shows continuous involvement of mucosa with no normal mucosa in between, which indicates ulcerative colitis. 

Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease resulting in superficial erosions confined to the mucosa and submucosa of the colon. It starts from the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous manner.

Colonoscopy shows loss of typical vascular pattern, granularity, friability, and ulceration involving the distal rectum, extending proximally in symmetric, continuous, and circumferential patterns. Fistula is not a complication of ulcerative colitis. 

Image B shows a cobblestone appearance seen in Crohn's disease. Normal mucosa in between the ulcers leads to this appearance. Fine granular mucosa is the earliest barium enema finding in Ulcerative colitis. Fistula is seen with Crohn’s disease.

Crohn's disease may occur in any area of the GI tract, but the most common sites involved at presentation are the terminal ileum, ileocecal valve, and cecum. It is associated with smoking.

 In Crohn's disease, the following are seen:

  • Aphthous ulcers - Small, shallow ulcers surrounded by erythema
  • Longitudinal ulcers - Linear or serpiginous deep ulcers 
  • Cobblestone appearance - Deep, longitudinal ulcerations interlaced with intervening normal mucosa
  • Strictures 
  • Fistulas

Other options:

Barrett's esophagus is a condition in which the mucosal lining of the swallowing tube that connects the mouth to the stomach (esophagus) becomes damaged by acid reflux, which causes the lining to thicken and become red. It is associated with an increased risk of developing esophageal cancer.

 

Mallory Weiss tear is due to a longitudinal tear in mucosa or submucosa of the gastroesophageal junction. It is most commonly seen in alcoholics, following forceful vomiting, retching, coughing, or staining. The left gastric artery is the most common vessel to bleed. The investigation of choice is endoscopy.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect regarding atrophic rhinitis?

choices.text: Klebsiella ozaenae is associated with primary atrophic rhinitis.
Sodium bicarbonate is not a component of kemicetine antiozaena solution
In Modified Young's operation, nostrils are partially closed.

questions.solution:
DNS causes unilateral atrophic rhinitis i.e. only on roomier side and in severe cases. 

In atrophic rhinitis/ozaena, ciliated columnar epithelium is lost and is replaced by stratified squamous epithelium. There is atrophy of seromucinous glands, venous blood sinusoids and nerve elements. Arteries in the mucosa, periosteum and bone show obliterating endarteritis. The bones of the turbinate undergoes resorption causing widening of nasal chambers.  

Clinical presentation - nasal obstruction, foul odor (merciful anosmia), crusting of the nasal passage, pale nasal mucosa, wide nasal turbinates, epistaxis

Etiology of atrophic rhinitis: 

Etiology of primary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Hereditary- Involves more than one member of a family
  • Endocrinal- More common in females, starts at puberty and regresses after menopause
  • Racial- More common in mongoloid and caucasian races
  • Nutritional deficiency- Vitamin A, D, iron deficiencies
  • Autoimmune- Antigens of the nasal mucosa
  • Organism- Klebsiella ozaenae

Etiology of secondary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Specific infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy and, rhinoscleroma
  • Long-standing purulent sinusitis
  • Radiotherapy to nose
  • Excessive surgical removal of turbinates
  • Diphtheroids, Proteus vulgaris, Escherichia coli, staphylococci and streptococci

 

MEDICAL Treatment
Nasal irrigation
  • warm saline
  • alkaline solution composed of
    • sodium bicarbonate 1 part,
    • sodium biborate 1 part,
    • sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water
Local antibiotics

Kemicetine antiozaena solution containing 

  • Chloramphenicol,
  • Oestradiol and
  • Vitamin D2. 
Others 
  • 25% glucose in glycerine
  • Oestrodiol spray
  • Placental extract
  • Streptomycin
  • Potassium iodide

Avoid decongestants (Phenylephrine) which can worsen the already compromised blood supply to nasal mucosa in atrophic rhinitis.

SURGICAL Treatment
Young's operation both the nostrils are closed completely
Modified Young's operation both the nostrils are closed partially
Narrowing the nasal cavities

    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia)
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale

questions.text: As a first-year resident assisting in a superficial parotidectomy, you have been asked to identify the facial nerve trunk. All of the following structures can be used for its localization, except ____.
questions.solution:
The inferior belly of the omohyoid muscle is not used as an anatomical landmark for the identification of the facial nerve trunk.

There are two methods for localization of the facial nerve trunk: 

1. Anterograde method: In this method, the facial nerve trunk is identified based on the anatomical landmarks after it exits from the stylomastoid foramen. The anatomical landmarks include:

  • Conley's pointer is the inferior portion of the cartilaginous canal. The facial nerve trunk lies 1 cm deep and inferior to its tip.
  • Posterior belly of digastric - The facial nerve lies superior to the upper border of the muscle.
  • Mastoid process - Upon drilling it, the nerve is identified proximally.
  • Squamotympanic fissure is a fissure in the temporal bone, which runs from TMJ to the tympanic cavity. The facial nerve runs through this fissure.
  • Styloid process - The facial nerve lies superficial to it.

2. Retrograde method: In this method, the main branches of the facial nerve trunk are identified and are then traced proximally until the main tunk is identified. Some of the main branches that are commonly used for tracing the facial nerve trunk include:

  • Buccal branch lies in relation to the parotid gland
  • Marginal mandibular branch lies in relation to the facial vessels
  • Temporal branch

The given image shows the anatomical relations useful for the localization of the facial nerve trunk.

questions.text: Which of the following would be seen in anemia of chronic disease?
questions.solution:
High serum ferritin levels are seen in anemia of chronic disease.

Anemia of chronic disease is anemia resulting due to chronic diseases which produce systemic inflammation. During chronic inflammation, inflammatory mediators like interleukin - 6(IL-6) stimulate the production of hepcidin from the liver. Hepcidin is an acute phase reactant that inhibits ferroportin on macrophages and also decreases iron from stores to developing RBC precursors. This results in decreased proliferation of erythroid progenitors due to impaired iron utilization.

By decreasing available serum iron, the body defends itself from certain bacteria(Eg, Hemophilus influenza) that require iron for their pathogenicity. The lab findings seen in anemia of chronic disease are:

  • Low serum iron
  • Decreased total iron-binding capacity
  • Abundant stored iron
  • Increased hepcidin levels
  • Increased serum ferritin

The chronic illnesses associated with  anemia of chronic disease can be grouped into three categories:

  1. Chronic microbial infections, such as osteomyelitis, bacterial endocarditis, and lung abscess
  2. Chronic immune disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis and regional enteritis
  3. Neoplasms, such as carcinomas of the lung and breast and Hodgkin lymphoma

Note: Hepcidin is the main regulator of iron absorption which is encoded by the HAMP gene and is defective in hemochromatosis. 

Given below is an image of iron absorption that shows ferroportin being inhibited by hepcidin at intestinal mucosal cells

  • Pharmacological

questions.text:
A 24-year-old lady who underwent suction evacuation for molar pregnancy visits you on postoperative week 8 for her follow-up. Which of the following is not done during the follow-up of this patient?
  1. Ask her for a history of any irregular vaginal bleeding, cough, or breathlessness.
  2. Perform an abdominal examination to look for the size of the uterus and the ovaries.
  3. Perform a pelvic examination to look for sub-urethral nodules
  4. Request for a serum hCG value, a pelvic ultrasound, and chest X-ray PA view 
  5. Insert a copper-T device to avoid pregnancy
questions.solution:
Insertion of a copper-T device to avoid pregnancy is not done during follow-up of this patient.

Intrauterine devices are contraindicated post-evacuation of molar pregnancy due to the increased risk of perforation. Intrauterine devices and progestogen-only pills cause irregular bleeding and are best avoided as they lead to suspicion of malignancy. Safer contraceptive choices for such patients include combined oral pills, injectable DMPA(depot-medroxyprogesterone acetate), progestin implant, barrier methods, and sterilization.

Contraception has to be adopted by all patients who underwent suction curettage until HCG levels become undetectable and remain the same for a period of 6 months. This serves to avoid pregnancy and confusion regarding the source of HCG if there is a subsequent rise. After beta HCG levels have become normal, subsequent conception must be avoided for one year(preferably 2 years). Pregnancy should also be avoided for 1 year after the stoppage of chemotherapy because of the teratogenic effect of drugs.

All patients should be followed-up for 2 years because choriocarcinoma if it occurs, develops within this period of the evacuation of the mole. Commonly, the circulating levels of βhCG decrease or becomes negative within 4 to 8 weeks post evacuation. Once negative, the patient is usually followed up monthly for 6 months, then 3 monthly in the first year, and 6 monthly in the second year.

During follow-up visits, history should be taken about symptoms like irregular bleeding (choriocarcinoma), presence of nodules, cough, breathlessness, and hemoptysis (metastasis). An abdominal examination should be done to check for involution of the uterus and ovarian size. A pelvic examination is done to look for sub-urethral nodules (anterior vaginal wall).

Lab investigations must include routine investigations like haemogram, renal function, liver function test, and urine routine. Specific investigations include thyroid function tests and serum βhCG (by radio-immunoassay). Persistently high values indicate pregnancy or invasive mole.

Radiological investigations should include a chest X-ray PA view to look for lung metastases (classic cannon-ball appearance can be seen). Pelvic ultrasound is also done for surveillance. Myometrial or suburethral nodules or hypervascularity may be a predictor of subsequent neoplasia. 

The given image shows the classical cannon-ball appearance on the chest X-ray.

Related Pearl: Risk factors and FIGO staging of Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia

Risk factors

  • Older age
  • β-hCG levels > 100,000 mIU/mL
  • Uterine size that is large-forgestational age
  • Theca-lutein cysts > 6 cm
  • Slow decline in β-hCG levels
  • Postevacuation uterine sonographic surveillance showing myometrial nodules or hypervascularity may be a predictor of subsequent neoplasia.

FIGO staging:

Stage I Disease confined to the uterus
Stage II GTD extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structure
Stage III Lung metastasis with or without genital tract involvement
Stage IV Other metastasis

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones (indicated by the arrow in the image below) giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: Identify the flap shown in the image used for breast reconstruction.
questions.solution:
The image shows a deep inferior epigastric perforator (DIEP) flap. It is a free flap and a variant of TRAM flap where only the skin and fat are moved to the chest.

Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous (TRAM) flap is either based on the superior or inferior epigastric artery or both (supercharged TRAM). In a TRAM flap, the skin, fat, and rectus muscle are moved to the chest. 

If robust DIEA perforators are identified with a good caliber and dissection can be performed without dividing the muscle, a DIEP flap is preferred. Otherwise, if small-caliber perforators are encountered and not aligned over the medial or lateral row, a TRAM flap is performed to ensure flap viability.

Option C: Latissimus dorsi (LD) flap is an axial flap based on the thoracodorsal pedicle.

questions.text: Given image illustrates the position of the fetus in a female, while in active labour. Choose the right statement with regards to this .

choices.text: Anterior fontanelle is palpable on vaginal examination
Head engages through left oblique diameter of maternal pelvis
Mandates C- section, as there is no mechanism of labor

questions.solution:
The given image is representative of the right occiput posterior position of the fetus, where the anterior fontanelle is palpable on vaginal examination.

Occcipitoposterior is an abnormal position of the vertex, where the occiput is placed posteriorly over the sacroiliac joint or directly over the sacrum. The right occiput posterior(ROP) is the most common variant in this category, where the occiput is placed over the right sacroiliac joint.

In more than 50% of cases, this position is associated with either an anthropoid or android pelvis(option A), as the wide occiput can comfortably be placed in the wider posterior segment of the pelvis.

Marked deflexion of the fetal head too favors the posterior position of the vertex.

On vaginal examination, the anterior fontanelle is felt easily because of deflexion of the head(option B). The sagittal suture occupies any of the oblique diameters of the pelvis.

The head engages through the right oblique diameter in ROP(option C) and the left oblique diameter in LOP. The engaging anteroposterior diameter is either suboccipitofrontal(10cm) or occipitofrontal(11.5cm).

In the majority of the cases(90%), anterior rotation of the occiput occurs by 3/8th of a circle(135 degrees) and delivery of the head occurs by extension. Hence, a C-section is not necessary(option D) routinely and is needed only in a minority of cases complicated by deep transverse arrest or occipitosacral arrest.

questions.text: A person travelling on flight experiences blockade sensation in his right ear, which then progressed to sharp pain during descent. Which of the following measures will prevent the occurrence of a similar episode in his next air travel?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms are suggestive of the middle ear barotrauma during flight descent. Using vasoconstrictor (oxymetazoline) nasal spray half an hour before descent can prevent this.

Otitic barotrauma is a non-suppurative condition resulting from the failure of the eustachian tube to maintain middle ear pressure at ambient atmospheric level. The usual cause is rapid descent during an air flight, underwater diving or compression in the pressure chamber.

Measures to prevent middle ear barotrauma:

  • Swallow repeatedly during descent (as swallowing opens up the eustachian tube and equalizes the middle ear pressure)
  • Avoid sleeping during descent as the number of swallows normally decrease during sleep
  • Auto inflation of the tube by Valsalva should be performed intermittently
  • Vasoconstrictor nasal spray/ antihistaminic and systemic decongestant tablet  half an hour before descent can effectively prevent this
  • Occlusive earplugs are contraindicated due to the risk of the external ear barotrauma

questions.text: A middle aged woman came with complaints of right sided colicky pain. USG showed mild hydronephrosis on the right side and a lower ureteric stone. She gives a history of recurrent urinary tract infections and intermittent hematuria in the past. The IVP image is given image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient is experiencing renal colic caused by a stone in the lower ureter. Given their history of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) and intermittent hematuria, an underlying condition should be considered. The IVP image reveals a "paintbrush" or "bouquet of flowers" appearance, which is characteristic of medullary sponge kidney (MSK).

Medullary sponge kidney (MSK) is a developmental defect that affects the formation of collecting tubules, resulting in cystic dilatation of the medullary and papillary portions of the collecting ducts. It is typically a sporadic, benign condition, often discovered incidentally.

It is marked by medullary cysts of varying sizes and is associated with distal renal tubular acidosis (RTA), which leads to hypercalciuria. This hypercalciuria increases the likelihood of forming calcium oxalate and calcium phosphate stones. Patients may also experience recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) and hematuria. Intravenous Pyelography (IVP) typically reveals a "paintbrush" or "bouquet of flowers" appearance, though CT urography has largely replaced this test for diagnosis.

Other options:

Option A: Duplex kidney is a condition associated with presence of duplicated ureters or collecting systems. This is due to the incomplete fusion of the upper and lower pole of the kidney.It has two separate pelvicalyceal systems draining single renal parenchyma.

On intravenous urogram it shows a "drooping lily" sign. It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system.

Option C: Horseshoe kidney is the most common congenital anomaly of the kidneys and is caused by the fusion of the lower poles of the kidney. The lower border of the kidneys usually lies in front of L3 vertebra due to the arrest of ascent. 

Option D: Maiden waist deformity refers to the appearance of the medial deviation of bilateral ureters. This is typically seen in retroperitoneal fibrosis. In this condition, there is a medial drawing of the ureter due to the deposition of fibrous tissue in the lumbosacral junction. Due to the involvement of both ureters, the course of the medially-drawn ureters has an appearance of a narrow maiden waist, thus giving the name.

questions.text: A young woman, who was diagnosed with threatened abortion was referred to you from the peripheral hospital for an USG (Ultrasonography). Examination of this patient would reveal:

Closed cervical os with fetal cardiac activity on USG

Dilated cervical os with fetal cardiac activity on USG

questions.solution:
Examination of a patient diagnosed with threatened abortion would reveal closed cervical os with fetal cardiac activity on USG.

In threatened miscarriage, the process of miscarriage has started but has not progressed to a state from which recovery is impossible.

questions.text: A patient presents with a seizure. On evaluation, urine osmolality is 1000 mOsm/Kg and serum osmolality is 270 mOsm/Kg. Which electrolyte abnormality can be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has high urine osmolality of 1000 mOsm/kg (normal 500-800 mOsm/kg) and low plasma osmolality of 270 mOsm/kg (normal 285-295 mOsm/kg). This is seen in the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone synthesis (SIADH) and hyponatremia is the most common electrolyte abnormality seen.

Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone ADH release (SIADH) is a condition where there is an unsuppressed release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) from the pituitary gland or nonpituitary sources or its continued action on vasopressin receptors.

ADH promotes the reabsorption of water from the collecting duct. Excessive secretion of ADH in SIADH results in enhanced water reabsorption. Therefore, only water is reabsorbed and not the solutes resulting in concentrated urine. This is depicted as high urine osmolality. The excess of water reabsorbed from the tubules expand and dilute the extracellular fluid leading to dilutional hyponatremia. This is depicted as low plasma osmolality. 

Since there is an increase in body water with little or no change in body sodium in SIADH, this is known as euvolemic hyponatremia.

Patients may be asymptomatic or present with headache, confusion, nausea, vomiting, anorexia, seizures, and coma.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents to you with the following lesion over the eye.  All the following statements regarding this condition are true except:

choices.text: It is usually a stationary condition
Associated with deposition of amorphous hyaline material in the conjunctiva
Temopral side is affected first and then the nasal side
There is elastotic degeneration of collagen fibres of conjunctiva

questions.solution:
The image shows pinguecula, which affects the nasal side first and then the temporal side.

Pinguecula is a degenerative condition of the conjunctiva, characterized by the formation of a yellowish-white patch on the bulbar conjunctiva near the limbus.

Features:

  • Usually found in elderly people, especially those exposed to strong sunlight, dust, wind, etc.
  • There is an elastotic degeneration of collagen fibres of the substantia propria of the conjunctiva, coupled with deposition of amorphous hyaline material in the substance of conjunctiva.
  • It is a stationary condition

Complications of pinguecula include its inflammation, intraepithelial abscess formation and rarely calcification.

No treatment is required. When inflamed, it is treated with topical steroid.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl was brought by her mother with complaints of abnormal gait. On examination, the child had a waddling gait and exaggerated lumbar lordosis. The mother gives a history of breech delivery and remembers that the pediatrician diagnosed a hip condition at that time, but it was ignored by the family. What should be the management at this stage?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of developmental or congenital dysplasia of the hip (DDH). In a child of age 18-36 months (2 years old), open reduction with osteotomy is done.

This osteotomy can be either femoral or pelvic or both. 

Pelvic osteotomies are of varieties as follows:

  • Salter's
  • Pemberton
  • Chiari
  • Steel
  • Shelf operations

Developmental dysplasia of the hip or congenital dysplasia of the hip is characterized by spontaneous dislocation of the hip joint before, during, or shortly after birth.

Risk factors for DDH include:

  • Sex of the baby- females are more susceptible to DDH due to the action of maternal relaxin on the fetal joints in-utero predisposing it to dislocation. It is 3-5 times more common in females.
  • Intrauterine positioning- breech position is associated with a higher incidence of DDH
  • Genetic predisposition- DDH is more common in children of parents who had DDH themselves.
  • First born child.

Examination of the developmental dysplasia of the hip:

1) Newborn to 3 months of age. Tests to check instability of the hip:

  • Asymmetrical skin creases in the inguinal, gluteal, and thigh regions.
  • Ortolani test: To perform this test, the infant is supine, with the hip and knee flexed. With the thumb placed over the medial thigh and the index finger on the greater trochanter, the hip is gently abducted. This reduces the femoral head into the acetabulum producing a palpable "clunk".
  • Barlow test: This test is done within 2–3 days of birth. To perform this test, the infant is supine with the knees fully flexed and the hip at 90° of flexion. Gentle adduction results in a posterior subluxation or dislocation of an easily dislocatable femoral head, producing a palpable "clunk".

2) At 3-6 months of age:

  • Galeazzi's test 
  • Marked asymmetry of the inguinal, gluteal, thigh, or popliteal folds.
  • Decreased abduction on the affected side.

3) In children of walking age:

  • Trendelenburg gait
  • Positive Trendelenburg sign
  • Limb-length discrepancy

Treatment of DDH includes early closed reduction with splinting or casts. If closed reduction cannot be achieved in long-standing dislocations, an open reduction may become necessary.

questions.text: A lady at 14 weeks of gestation presents with abdominal pain and persistent browny vaginal discharge for a few days. On examination, the uterus appears smaller than the period of gestation with a closed cervical os. Doppler ultrasound reveals non-audibility of the fetal heart sound which was audible before. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a woman with 14 weeks of gestation presenting with abdominal pain, persistent browny vaginal discharge, smaller uterus for gestation, closed cervical os, non-audibility of the fetal heart sound in ultrasound is suggestive of missed miscarriage.

Missed miscarriage or early fetal demise is termed when the fetus is dead and retained inside the uterus for a variable period.

Patients usually present with features of threatened miscarriage like dull pain or bleeding per vaginum followed by:

  • Persistence of brownish vaginal discharge
  • Subsidence of pregnancy symptoms
  • Retrogression of breast changes
  • The uterus appears smaller in size (cessation of uterine growth)
  • Nonaudibility of the fetal heart sound
  • Closed cervical os
  • Cervix feels firm
  • Negative immunological test for pregnancy
  • Empty sac in real-time ultrasonography

Beyond 12 weeks, the retained fetus in the uterus becomes macerated and mummified. 

The expulsion or extraction from the mother of an embryo or fetus weighing 500 g or less when it is not capable of independent survival is termed abortion.

Classification of abortion:

Other options:

Option A- Inevitable miscarriage is the type of abortion where continuation of pregnancy is impossible.

Features:

  • Increased vaginal bleeding
  • Aggravation of pain in the lower abdomen which may be colicky in nature
  • Dilated internal os
  • Rupture of the membranes

Option C- Threatened miscarriage is the type of abortion where the process of miscarriage has started but in a state from which recovery is possible. 

Features:

  • Bleeding which is usually slight and may be brownish or bright red in color
  • Usually painless but pain appears following hemorrhage
  • Closed external os
  • Uterine size corresponds to the period of amenorrhea
  • The uterus and cervix feel soft
  • On ultrasound:
    • Well-formed gestation ring
    • Presence of fetal cardiac motion 

Option D- Complete miscarriage is termed when products of conception are expelled en masse.

Features:

  • Abdominal pain subsides
  • Decreased or absent vaginal bleeding
  • The uterus is smaller than the period of amenorrhea
  • The cervical os is closed
  • Examination of the expelled fleshy mass is found complete.
  • Ultrasound shows an empty uterine cavity

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is found to have a renal mass in the right kidney during the abdominal ultrasound. He does not complain of any symptoms. The doctor advised contrast-enhanced CT for the evaluation of the renal mass. It shows the presence of a central stellate scar. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A central stellate scar on computed tomography (CT) scan is seen in oncocytoma.

Oncocytoma

  • It is a benign tumor arising from the distal renal tubules
  • Most common benign tumor that appears as an enhancing renal mass on cross-sectional imaging.
  • A central stellate scar is observed in imaging studies.
  • Histology reveals large eosinophilic cells (owing to an abundance of mitochondria) arranged in distinct nests.

questions.text: A person posted for nephrolithotomy was placed in a surgical position as shown in the image below. Traction injury of which of the following structures is a potential complication of this position?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the lateral or kidney position used in urological and retroperitoneal procedures. Traction injury of the brachial plexus is a potential complication of this position.

The modified lateral position called the kidney position is used in urological and retroperitoneal procedures. Here, the lower leg of the patient is slightly flexed at the knee. A pillow is placed between both legs and the upper leg is flexed in a more exaggerated position. Arms are fixed in the stirrups.

Complications associated with this procedure are:

  • Respiratory complications due to more ventilation of one lung over the other.
  • Traction injury of the brachial plexus and ulnar nerve.
  • Corneal abrasions and ocular trauma.

Entrapment of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is seen with lithotomy position, prone position and beach chair position.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient presented to the emergency room with severe chest and back pain. Contrast-enhanced CT revealed a Stanford type B aortic dissection. What would be the initial management in this case?
questions.solution:
The initial management of a patient presenting with Stanford type B aortic dissection is the administration of anti-hypertensives.

Aortic dissection is initiated by an intimal tear and most commonly occurs in middle-aged and elderly hypertensive patients. Clinically, patients present with tearing intrascapular pain.

Classification of aortic dissection:

Acute aortic dissection can be classified in two ways: the original DeBakey system, which is based on the location of the proximal tear and distal extent of the dissection flap, and the Stanford system, which is based only on the location of the proximal tear. 

Site of dissection DeBakey Stanford
Both ascending and descending aorta Type I Type A
Only ascending aorta and arch of the aorta Type II Type A

Descending aorta distal to the subclavian artery

Type IIIa

Limited to the thoracic aorta

 Type B

Type IIIb

Extends to the abdominal aorta

Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the investigation of choice in a hemodynamically unstable patient. In hemodynamically stable patients, the diagnosis is established with a contrast-enhanced CT scan. The characteristic diagnostic finding is a double-lumen aorta. 

Treatment options:

Ascending aortic dissection that includes Stanford Type A (DeBakey Types I and II) requires surgical intervention once the patient's blood pressure is stabilized.

Descending aortic dissection that includes Stanford Type B (DeBakey Type III) is initially best managed nonoperatively by antihypertensive drugs. Surgical intervention is indicated in complicated cases if the pain increases (signaling impending rupture) or when there is evidence of malperfusion of organs or neurological symptoms.

questions.text: Gold standard investigation before Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS) is?
questions.solution:
The gold standard investigation before FESS is a CT scan to rule out other pathologies and for confirmation of diagnosis. CT scan is better than MRI for visualizing bones and their anatomy.

Even while doing surgery, decisions on whether to open the mastoid antrum are based on CT findings and intraoperative findings. FESS is done for failed medical management of rhinosinusitis.

Other indications of FESS:

  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis that is unresponsive to adequate medical treatment.
  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis
  • Polypoid rhinosinusitis (diffuse nasal polyposis)
  • Fungal sinusitis with a fungal ball or nasal polypi
  • Antrochoanal polyp
  • Mucocele of frontoethmoid or sphenoid sinus
  • Control of epistaxis by endoscopic cautery.
  • Removal of foreign body from the nose or sinus
  • Endoscopic septoplasty

Advanced nasal endoscopic techniques

  • Removal of benign tumors, e.g. inverted papillomas or angiofibromas.
  • Orbital abscess or cellulitis management.
  • Dacryocystorhinostomy
  • Repair of CSF leak
  • Pituitary surgery
  • Optic nerve decompression
  • Orbital decompression for Graves’ disease
  • Control of posterior epistaxis (endoscopic clipping of sphenopalatine artery)
  • Choanal atresia.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the casualty following a fall on an outstretched hand. He complains of pain in his left elbow. Examination reveals tenderness and swelling over his left elbow. An X-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following statements is true with respect to this condition?

choices.text: Vascular injury commonly involves the brachial artery
Ulnar nerve  is most commonly injured in the extension-type
Almost all injuries are of the flexion-type
Cubitus valgus is the most common angular deformity

questions.solution:
The clinical features and x-ray showing posterior fat pad sign are suggestive of supracondylar fracture of the humerus where vascular injury commonly involves the brachial artery.

Supracondylar fracture of humerus:

It is most commonly seen in children of 5-7 years. The extension type is seen in 98% of the cases while the rest are flexion type. The mechanism of injury involved is usually a fall on an outstretched hand with an elbow in full extension. Gartland classification is used for the classification of supracondylar fractures and is of four types.

On examination:

There may be an S-shaped deformity at the elbow. If the proximal fracture fragment is sharp and has penetrated the muscles and fascia, a dimple may be seen on the skin above the elbow (dimple sign). The three-point bony relationship is maintained in supracondylar fracture.

Radiology:  

  • An undisplaced fracture may show a triangular lucency like a sail of a yacht (sail sign), also called a fat pad sign. This is due to the fat pad around the elbow being pushed forward by hematoma.
  • Baumann’s angle is the angle between the horizontal line of the elbow and the line drawn through the lateral epiphysis and long axis of the arm. It is normally less than 5 degrees and is checked with the other arm.

The most common nerve to be injured in extension type is the anterior interosseous nerve while the ulnar nerve is injured in flexion type. The brachial artery is most likely involved when there are blood vessel involvement.

Cubitus Varus deformity:

Cubitus varus or gunstock deformity is the most common angular deformity that results from supracondylar fractures in children. The static deformities of cubitus varus with respect to the distal fragment are :

  • Posterior displacement
  • Horizontal rotation
  • Coronal tilt.

Treatment: 

Conservative management is attempted with closed reduction using traction and counter-traction. Successful reduction is when the long axis of arm and forearm lie in parallel. If conservative management fails, skin or skeletal traction is employed but is not used anymore due to better modalities of treatment.

Surgery is by either closed reduction and percutaneous internal fixation with K-wires or open reduction and internal fixation with wires or plates.

Other options:

Option B: The most common nerve injury in extension-type supracondylar fractures is actually to the median nerve, not the ulnar nerve. The ulnar nerve is more commonly injured in flexion-type fractures.

Option C: The majority of supracondylar fractures in children are of the extension-type, not the flexion-type. 

Option D: The most common angular deformity after a supracondylar fracture is cubitus varus (Gunstock deformity), not cubitus valgus.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident, and an eFAST was performed. What is the additional view incorporated to this imaging modality?
questions.solution:
Focussed Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST) is extended into the thoracic cavities and peri­cardium (eFAST), where anterior pleural views are incorporated. It is a technique in which ultrasonography is used to assess the presence of free fluid in the abdominal cavity. 

It is a rapid, non-invasive bedside test for detecting free fluid in the abdomen using sonography used to assess patients for potential thoracoabdominal injuries. 

The patient is placed in a supine position. With a 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer the following regions are scanned :

  • Subxiphoid transverse view(also called subcostal view or pericardial view)
  • Right upper quadrant view (also called right flank view or perihepatic view)
  • Left upper quadrant view (also called Perisplenic or left flank view) 
  • Suprapubic view or Pelvic view

An extended FAST or eFAST scan incorporates the Anterior pleural views to assess the anterior thorax.

Drawbacks of FAST:

  • Does not reliably detect less than 100 mL of free blood
  • Does not directly identify hollow viscus injury or penetrating trauma
  • Often requires supplementing with other investigations
  • Does not assess the retroperitoneum

questions.text: Out of the following, which is the most common site of osteoporotic fracture?
questions.solution:
Out of the following options, vertebral fractures are most commonly seen in osteoporosis 

The fractures are classically low trauma deﬁned as a fall from standing height or less. Fracture ofthe distal radius (Colles’ fracture) is usually the ﬁrst fracture to occur, followed by vertebrae and hip unless treatment is initiated. Osteoporotic vertebral fractures are particularly difﬁcult to diagnose as they may be clinically silent.  In severe cases, signiﬁcant height loss (often exceeding 4 cm)and thoracic kyphosis can occur due to multiple vertebral fractures.

Osteoporosis is a common metabolic bone disease characterized by a diffuse reduction in bone density due to a decrease in bone mass. A DEXA (dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry) scan is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis and assessment of severity.

The mainstay of treatment is to reduce the risk of fractures. The following medications can be useful in the treatment:

  • Bisphosphonates - They are the first line of medication. They reduce osteoclastic bone resorption and prevent bone loss. Eg. Zoledronate.
  • Denosumab - This is an antibody to the RANK ligand. It prevents the activation of RANK which is required for the proliferation of osteoclasts. Therefore, it decreases bone resorption.
  • Parathyroid hormone - Teriparatide is a recombinant parathyroid hormone analog. At low and intermittent doses, they can promote bone formation.
  • Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) - They act on the estrogen receptors and prevent bone resorption. Eg. raloxifene.
  • Strontium ranelate - It is thought to increase bone formation and reduce bone resorption.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old boy was brought to the casualty with fever, pruritus, wheezing, jaundice, and colicky abdominal pain which did not subside with analgesics. USG showed a dilated common bile duct with an echogenic structure. An ERCP later performed shows the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?

USG - ultrasonography; ERCP - Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangio Pancreaticography
questions.solution:
The patient exhibits clinical manifestations consistent with cholangitis. An ultrasound of the abdomen detects a dilated common bile duct as well as an echogenic structure, and an ERCP reveals a linear filling defect. These findings provide evidence in favor of the patient's intraluminal ascaris infection.

The given Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangio Pancreaticography (ERCP) shows linear filling defect characteristic of worm in the biliary tree. One of the commonly found worms in the biliary tree is Ascaris. The worm may also be seen as parallel filling defects - railway track sign. The same image has been marked with arrows to help appreciate the presence of this worm in the bile duct.

ERCP stands for Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangio Pancreaticography. A side-viewing endoscope is passed through the pylorus of the stomach into the second part of the duodenum to visualize the papilla. It is then cannulated, and dye is injected into the pancreatic or bile duct to visualize the pancreatic or biliary tree. It can be both therapeutic and diagnostic.

Ascaris lumbricoides is an intestinal nematode that causes ascariasis. Infection occurs through food or water contaminated with nightsoil or human feces having eggs of Ascaris. These eggs contain the infective rhabditiform larva. The image given below depicts the life cycle of Ascaris lumbricoides.

Other options:

Option A: Bile duct strictures are areas where the intrahepatic or extrahepatic biliary ductal system narrows. The constriction blocks the usual forward flow of bile, leading to widening upstream and causing serious health issues due to the effects of bile duct blockage. Below is an ERCP showing the presence of a distal bile duct stricture.

Option B: Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the intrahepatic and/or extrahepatic biliary tree. They are 4 times more common in females. They present with a triad of jaundice, a palpable right upper quadrant mass, and abdominal pain. However, they may remain minimally symptomatic and may escape detection. Below is an ERCP image depicting a type 1B choledochal cyst.

Option C: Choledocholithiasis or common bile duct stones are classified based on their point of origin. Choledocholithiasis is mostly clinically silent but may present with biliary colic and even obstructive jaundice. The following ERCP image shows a round filling defect (marked with an arrow) within the common bile duct indicative of choledocholithiasis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who is in the third trimester of pregnancy started to experience pain in her left leg. She also noticed that her left leg was turning pale and edematous as given in the image below. What is the cause of this condition?

choices.text: Femoral vein thrombosis and lymphatic obstruction
Due to pressure exerted by uterus on the iliac veins

questions.solution:
The patient is having phlegmasia alba dolens also known milk leg or white leg. It is due to ileofemoral deep vein thrombosis.

It is usually seen in pregnant women and in individuals at risk of developing deep vein thrombosis. They typically present with painful, oedematous, and pale lower limb that blanches to touch. The lack of cyanosis differentiates this entity from phlegmasia cerulea dolens.

In phlegmasia alba dolens, the thrombosis involves only major deep venous channels of the extremity, thus sparing collateral veins. The venous drainage is decreased but still present.

In phlegmasia cerulea dolens, the thrombosis extends to collateral veins, resulting in severe venous congestion with massive fluid sequestration and more significant edema.

Both phlegmasia cerulea dolens and phlegmasia alba dolens results from acute massive deep vein thrombosis and can be complicated by venous gangrene.

Edema of pregnancy does not present with pain in the lower limbs but edema due to pressure exerted by the gravid uterus on the iliac veins.

questions.text: As an anaesthesia resident, you see the following curve in the capnograph. What would your next step be?

choices.text: Observation as the capnograph is normal

questions.solution:
The capnograph depicts a presentation of malignant hyperthermia. Removal of the offending agent and rapid administration of dantrolene sodium will be the next step in management.

When volatile anaesthetics or succinylcholine are used, malignant hyperthermia should be suspected in case of an unexpected rise in end-tidal CO2 ( ETCO2), This is considered to be one of the earliest and most sensitive indicators of malignant hyperthermia. It can supported by taking arterial blood gas reports with metabolic acidosis.

Malignant hyperthermia is a rare genetic hypermetabolic disease of the muscle. It occurs due to a mutation of the gene for the ryanodine receptor (Ryr 1), located on chromosome 19. It is an ion channel responsible for calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

The key clinical features are:

  • Succinylcholine-induced masseter muscle rigidity (causing trismus) or generalized muscle rigidity
  • Tachycardia
  • Hypercarbia (increased CO2 production) and reduced oxygen saturation
  • Hyperthermia (rise of 1° Celsius can occur every 5 minutes)
  • Arrhythmia
  • Hypertension
  • Myoglobinuria and myoglobinemia indicate muscle damage
  • Metabolic derangements like hyperkalemia and mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis

Treatment is to discontinue the triggering agents i.e. succinylcholine followed by administration of 100% oxygen.

Dantrolene sodium is the drug of choice. It is given rapidly at a dose of 2.5 mg/ kg intravenously and can be repeated every 5-10 minutes till the attack subsides.

Metabolic acidosis and hyperkalemia need to be corrected.

Hyperthermia must be controlled by cooling the patient. 

Continuous monitoring in intensive care is required for 24 to 48 hours.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who underwent dilatation and curettage previously, now presents with amenorrhea. The urine pregnancy test is negative. HSG revealed a honeycomb appearance in the uterine cavity. The hysteroscopic evaluation revealed 75% adhesions with agglutinations of the uterine wall. This is classified as ______?

choices.text: Cannot be classified with the given information

questions.solution:
The given clinical features, history and hysteroscopy is suggestive of Asherman syndrome where 75% adhesions with agglutinations is classified as Severe Asherman syndrome.

Asherman syndrome (uterine synechiae) is classified as follows:

  • Mild: <25% adhesion involves the uterine cavity, flimsy adhesions involving the fundus and tubal ostia.
  • Moderate: 25–70% adhesion of the endometrial surfaces, but no agglutination of the uterine wall.
  • Severe: 75% adhesions with agglutination and thick adhesions.

Asherman syndrome can be caused by the following:

  • Dilatation and curettage (D&C) 
  • Medical termination of pregnancy (MTP), spontaneous abortions, recurrent abortions
  • Uterine packing in postpartum haemorrhage
  • Uterine infection
  • Tubercular endometritis

It causes secondary amenorrhoea, oligomenorrhoea, dysmenorrhoea, habitual abortion and infertility depending upon the extent of uterine cavity obliteration.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida at 18 weeks of gestation presents for her antenatal check-up. Her random plasma glucose level was 243 mg/dL and thus she was asked to undergo further tests. The fasting blood glucose levels were 146mg/dL and HbA1c was 7.6%.  Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A fasting blood sugar > 126 mg/dL , random blood sugar > 200mg/dL and HbA1c> 6.5% is suggestive of overt diabetes or pregestational diabetes. 

The following are the lab results that would be suggestive of overt diabetes in a mother.

  • Fasting blood sugar at least 126 mg/dL
  • A random blood sugar of at least 200 mg/dL
  • HbA1c of at least 6.5%

Cardiac anomalies are most commonly seen in the fetuses of overt-diabetic mothers. Musculoskeletal, urogenital, and CNS anomalies are also seen,

Congenital malformations occur at a higher rate, in overt diabetes than in gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). This is because GDM manifests in the second trimester and by then organogenesis would be complete.

Threshold values for gestational diabetes (75 g OGTT):

According to WHO and ADA guidelines, the one-step approach omits the screening test and simplifies diagnostic testing for gestational diabetes mellitus by performing only a 75-gram, two-hour oral GTT.

Diagnostic criteria or cut-off values with a 75 g OGTT are as follows:

  • Fasting: 92 mg/dl 
  • 1 hour: 180 mg/dl  
  • 2 hours: 153 mg/dl

Two-step approach :

  • The first step (screening) is a 50-gram one-hour glucose challenge test (GCT) at 24-28 weeks of gestation who are not previously diagnosed with diabetes.
  • If the plasma glucose level measured 1 h after the load is ≥130, a 100-gram, three-hour oral glucose tolerance test (GTT) is done, which is the diagnostic test for gestational diabetes mellitus.

 At least 2 of the following 4 values should be raised for a diagnosis to be made:

  • Fasting: 95 mg/dL (5.3 mmol/L)
  • 1 h: 180 mg/dL (10.0 mmol/L)
  • 2 h: 155 mg/dL (8.6 mmol/L)
  • 3 h: 140 mg/dL (7.8 mmol/L)

Option A: MODY or maturity-onset diabetes of the young is a monogenic form of diabetes that occurs < 25 years. There is impaired insulin secretion, but no antibodies.

Option D: LADA  is a form of diabetes mellitus affecting lean and thin adults less than 50 years with a positive family history. It is insulin-dependent and associated with autoantibodies.
