questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with a penetrating injury to his left eye for which he was treated with corneoscleral suturing and discharged a week later. He returns 2 months later complaining of diminished vision, associated with redness, pain, and photophobia in the right eye. Direct ophthalmoscopy revealed discrete yellow-white nodules in the fundus. What part of the eye is most commonly affected?
questions.solution:
The clinical case is suggestive of sympathetic ophthalmitis, which is a bilateral granulomatous panuveitis and hence the affected part is the uvea.

Dalen–Fuchs nodules are seen below the retinal pigment epithelium on ophtalmoscopy.

Sympathetic Ophthalmitis (SO) is a bilateral granulomatous panuveitis occurring after penetrating trauma which usually begins 4–8 weeks after the injury to the eye (the exciting eye). It can also develop after surgeries, proton beam irradiation, Nd: YAG photocoagulation, and cryotherapy. It is an delayed hypersensitivity reaction mediated by T cells.

The exciting eye is often red and irritable, and the sympathizing eye may develop irritation, blurred vision, photophobia, and loss of accommodation.

Fundoscopy:

  • Multifocal choroidal infiltrates
  • Infiltrates corresponding to Dalen–Fuchs nodules are seen below the retinal pigment epithelium
  • Exudative retinal detachment, vasculitis, and optic disc swelling
  • Residual chorioretinal scarring gives a sunset glow appearance when the inflammation settles

Treatment :

  • Steroids are the basis of treatment.
    • High-dose oral prednisolone is given for several months.
    • Supplementary topical steroids and cycloplegics for anterior uveitis
    • Periocular and intraocular steroids, slow-release intravitreal implants may also be used
  • Immunosuppressives such as azathioprine, ciclosporin, and methotrexate are used in resistant cases or as steroid-sparing agents. 
  • Enucleation of an eye with no visual potential within 2 weeks of injury prevents the occurrence of sympathetic ophthalmitis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with short bowel syndrome has 90 cm of residual jejunum following small bowel resection. Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: The patients should be encouraged to consume more water (> 5 Litres per day)
Saline replacement solutions with salt concentration of at least 45 mol/L should be administered
Antisecretory drugs such as H2-receptor antagonists are contraindicated.

questions.solution:
The patient is a NET secretor.

Net secretors are those patients having less than 100 cm of residual jejunum.

The patients with "Short Bowel Syndrome" who have had in excess of 200 cm of small bowel resected together with colectomy (and usually have a jejunostomy), are divided into two groups:

  • Net absorbers: >100 cm of residual jejunum
  • Net secretors: <100 cm of residual jejunum

Net secretors: Treatment begins with restricting the total amount of hypotonic fluids (such as water) consumed to less than a litre a day.

Patients are encouraged to take glucose and saline replacement solutions, which have a sodium concentration of at least 90 mmol/L (e.g.,WHO cholera solution)

Antisecretory drugs which include H2-receptor antagonists, proton pump inhibitors and the somatostatin analogue octreotide, are also used.

questions.text: On auscultation of a patient, a murmur was heard which is depicted by the following phonocardiogram. Which of the given conditions is most likely to produce this murmur?
questions.solution:
The phonocardiogram given above is of an ejection systolic murmur, which is seen in aortic stenosis. It is also heard in pulmonary stenosis. They are differentiated based on the difference in symptoms, site of murmur, etc.

 Clinical findings in aortic stenosis:

  • Pulse - slow rising and late peaking pulse which is known as pulsus parvus et tardus. A carotid thrill may also be palpated over these arteries.
  • Apical impulse - A double apical impulse may be recognized, and in the later stages, it may be displaced laterally.

Auscultation findings in aortic stenosis:

  • Early systolic ejection sound - heard in early stages, disappears when the valve becomes calcified and rigid
  • Paradoxical splitting of S2 - With worsening of stenosis, delayed closure of the aortic valve occurs. This leads to narrowing of S2 sound, and in severe cases, leads to paradoxical splitting of S2.
  • S4 and S3 - heard in severe cases
  • Ejection systolic murmur - starts after S1, increases in intensity to reach the peak, and ends before A2. It radiates to the neck and base of the heart. It is augmented by squatting and reduced by the strain of the Valsalva maneuver.

questions.text: The remnants of Wolffian ducts in females are located in________.
questions.solution:
The Gartner's duct is a remnant of the Wolffian ducts in women. These are located in the broad ligament and the vagina.

The Gartner's duct is an embryological remnant of the mesonephric duct/Wolffian duct formed during the development of the urinary and reproductive organs. It runs parallel to, but below, the fallopian tube in the mesosalpinx. The duct passes downwards by the side of the uterus to the level of the internal os where it passes into the tissues of the cervix. It then runs forwards to reach the anterolateral aspect of the vaginal wall and may reach as far down as the hymen.

The duct can sometimes form a cyst in the broad ligament or the vagina. It is called Gartner’s cyst. It is a benign condition and can be treated with marsupialization.

questions.text: A male patient comes with acute chest pain for the past one hour. ECG shows ST segment elevation in the leads II, III and aVF. What is the most appropriate intervention?
questions.solution:
The patient given in the scenario with sudden onset chest pain and ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF is suggestive of inferior wall MI and the most appropriate intervention is primary angioplasty. This intervention aims to restore blood flow to the affected coronary artery promptly and is associated with improved outcomes in acute STEMI compared to fibrinolytic therapy when performed.

Inferior wall MI mainly occurs due to blockage of the posterior descending branch of the right coronary artery. While anterior wall infarction shows sympathetic nervous system hyperactivity (tachycardia and hypertension), the inferior wall MI shows parasympathetic hyperactivity (bradycardia and hypotension).

Morphine and nitrates are contraindicated in an inferior wall MI due to the risk of further impairing the right ventricular preload.

Beta blockers (Option D) are generally not recommended either, due to the risk of the MI involving the AV node. Beta blockers can block the AV node which can lead to further AV blocks. 

Other options:

Option B: Dabigatran is an anticoagulant medication commonly used for the prevention of stroke and systemic embolism in patients with atrial fibrillation and for the treatment and prevention of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. However, it is not indicated as the initial treatment for acute ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).

Option C: Streptokinase is another fibrinolytic agent used for thrombolysis in the treatment of acute myocardial infarction, acute ischemic stroke, and acute pulmonary embolism. It is considered only an alternative reperfusion strategy in acute STEMI when primary angioplasty is unavailable or contraindicated.

The following protocol must be followed in the management of patients with acute coronary syndrome:

  1. Stabilization of airway, breathing and circulation.
  2. Administration of O2
  3. Give aspirin 325 mg and clopidogrel
  4. History and examination, assess cardiac biomarkers.
  5. Give up to three sublingual nitroglycerin tablets each 5 min apart till the pain subsides. Add IV nitroglycerin for the persistence of symptoms.
  6. Treat left heart failure if present with an after-load reducing agent or loop diuretic.
  7. Give beta blockers if there are no features of heart failure.
  8. Give morphine for the persistence of anxiety and discomfort related to MI.
  9. In patients with STEMI - Reperfusion with Percutaneous coronary intervention(PCI) or fibrinolysis (if PCI is unavailable within 120 min). is followed by antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy. In patients with NSTEMI - antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy is indicated.

questions.text: Which of the following is an early feature of maxillary carcinoma?

  • Facial paraesthesias 
  • Pain
  • Epiphora.

These symptoms may be missed or simply treated as sinusitis.

Option B: Lymphatic spread occurs in the late stages of the disease. Among the cervical lymph nodes, submandibular and upper jugular lymph nodes are enlarged.

questions.text: Which is the anaesthesia of choice in a day care dental surgery?
questions.solution:
Infiltration anesthesia is ideal to perform in day care dental procedures as a fast-track procedure.

It has a lesser incidence of complications than regional or general anesthesia. Other anesthetic techniques for hernia repair include intercostal block and ilioinguinal nerve block.

Ambulatory/Outpatient anesthesia employs the use of fast - Track surgical techniques to provide adequate surgical anesthesia and minimize post-operative complications in order to reduce the duration of hospital stay.

Disadvantage of infiltration anesthesia - Short duration of anesthesia even when long-acting local anesthetics like bupivacaine are used. Extended- duration local anesthesia can be produced by encapsulating bupivacaine into a biodegradable carrier.

Regional anesthesia is contraindicated in patients with bleeding disorders, those on anticoagulants and with local infections.

Spinal anesthesia has the disadvantage over epidural anesthesia of delayed recovery due to profound motor blockade. Spinal opioids like fentanyl or sufentanil are added to prolong postoperative analgesia and minimize motor block without delaying recovery. But the adverse effects of spinal opioids like nausea, pruritus and postoperative urinary retention are additive.

questions.text: A female patient presented to the emergency room with right-sided flank pain radiating to the groin since 1 day. Urinalysis shows crystals as seen below. What are these crystals made up of?
questions.solution:
Dumbbell-shaped and envelope-shaped crystals in this patient are indicative of calcium oxalate stones.

The classic presentation for a patient with nephrolithiasis (renal calculi) is acute renal colic which is the sudden onset of severe pain originating in the flank and radiating inferiorly and anteriorly (loin to groin). It is usually accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and hematuria. Urinalysis showing dumbbell and envelope-shaped crystals confirm that the kidney stones are made up of calcium oxalate. 

Risk factors for calcium oxalate stones:

  • Hyperparathyroidism (Causes hypercalcemia)
  • Hypercalciuria with normal serum calcium:
    • Hyperabsorption of calcium from the intestine (absorptive hypercalciuria)
    • Intrinsic impairment in renal tubular reabsorption of calcium (renal hypercalciuria)
    • Idiopathic fasting hypercalciuria with normal parathyroid function
  • Hyperoxaluria: Hereditary or acquired (intestinal malabsorption syndromes or excess intake of oxalate)
  • Hyperuricosuria
  • Hypocitraturia: Due to idiopathic causes, acidosis or chronic diarrhea.

There are four main types of calculi

  • Calcium stones (most common): composed of calcium oxalate or calcium oxalate mixed with calcium phosphate
  • Triple stones or struvite stones: composed of magnesium ammonium phosphate
  • Uric acid stones 
  • Cystine

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: Which of the following ligaments is most likely injured after a dashboard injury?

During a dashboard injury, the strong force on the anterior aspect of the tibia causes posterior translation of the tibia with respect to the femur, which results in posterior cruciate ligament injury.

The patient usually presents with a swollen and tender knee with hemarthrosis. The posterior drawer test to identify the posterior cruciate ligament tear is difficult to perform because of the pain and swelling. X-ray of the knee shows effusion. The posterior cruciate ligament injury can be definitively diagnosed with MRI as shown below.

Dashboard injury can lead to

  • Patellar fracture
  • Fracture neck of femur
  • Acetabular fracture
  • Shaft of femur fracture
  • Posterior cruciate ligament injury

Other options:

Option a : A posteriorly directed force on the anterior aspect of the tibia is unlikely to cause an anterior cruciate ligament injury.

Options c : Medial collateral ligament injury occurs due to stress on the lateral knee during sports (valgus stress injury).

Option d : Lateral collateral ligament injury occurs due to stress on the medial aspect of the knee (varus stress injury).

Her current vitals are HR- 62 bpm, BP- 100/60 mm Hg, SpO2- 95%, RR- 12/min, and temperature- 36.5°C. Her present ECG is shown below. Which of the following is not part of her critical care management?

choices.text: Use of waveform capnography to monitor endotracheal tube placement
Achieving target mean arterial pressure of >65mm Hg
Coronary angiography once the patient is out of coma
Achieve a core body temperature of 32-36 degree Celsius for at least 24 hours

questions.solution:
In a post-cardiac arrest patient with features of STEMI, coronary angiography must be performed on an emergency basis, irrespective of whether the patient is awake or comatose. 

Post cardiac-arrest care is the fifth link in the chain of survival, in cardiac arrest. It involves several components aimed at improving the likelihood of patient survival after the return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC) has been achieved. This patient seems to have suffered an arrest due to an anterior wall myocardial infarction as evidenced by the ECG showing ST elevation in leads V1 to V4 and hence needs immediate angiography to treat the cause of the arrest. Any delay predisposes her to rearrest, which is accompanied by a poor prognosis.

Other options:

Option A: The use of waveform capnography is advocated to be the most reliable way to monitor endotracheal tube placement.

Option B: The goal of hemodynamic stability is to achieve a systolic BP>90 mm Hg or mean arterial pressure of >65mm Hg.

Option D: Targeted temperature management(TTM) is the only intervention demonstrated to improve neurological recovery after cardiac arrest and involves maintaining core body temperature between 32-36°C for at least 24 hours.

questions.text: A 75-year-old female patient presented with complaints of poor vision, eye pain, photophobia, and watering from her right eye along with headache for the past one week. Examination reduced visual acuity with only light perception, a deep anterior chamber, and the finding as shown in the image. Intraocular pressure increased. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a patient with signs and symptoms of glaucoma (diminution of vision, eye pain, photophobia, watering, headache, corneal edema, mid-dilated pupils, raised intraocular pressure) occurring in association with a senile hyper mature Morgagnian cataract (as shown in the image). Presence of a deep anterior chamber points towards the diagnosis of secondary open-angle glaucoma - phacolytic glaucoma.

Phacolytic glaucoma is secondary open-angle glaucoma occurring in association with hyper mature morgagnian cataracts.

Trabecular obstruction is caused by high molecular-weight lens proteins that leak through the intact capsule in cases of the hyper mature cataract into the aqueous humour; macrophages containing lens proteins may also contribute to this.

Presentation:

  • Eye pain
  • Diminished vision
  • Photophobia
  • Lacrimation 
  • Headache
  • Increased intraocular pressure
  • Deep anterior chamber with fine white protein particles which may settle as pseudohypopyon
  • Open-angle seen on gonioscopy
  • Lens: Milky white cortex with sunken brownish nucleus (Morgagnian cataract)

Treatment:

  1. Medical therapy to lower the intraocular pressure
  2. Surgery to extract the lens.

Option A: Phacogenic (previously phacoanaphylactic) glaucoma is an autoimmune granulomatous reaction to lens proteins following exposure due to incomplete cataract extraction, trauma, or rarely capsular degeneration. The patient usually presents with a history of trauma or ocular surgery and a latent period following which the symptoms of glaucoma manifests. It is also a type of secondary open-angle glaucoma. 

Option B: Phacomorphic glaucoma is an acute secondary angle-closure glaucoma caused by an intumescent cataractous lens due to rapid maturation of cataract or following traumatic capsular rupture. The swollen lens obliterates the angle by forcing the root of the iris against the cornea. The patient presents with features of acute glaucoma with a shallow anterior chamber and a swollen cataractous lens.

Option D: Phacotopic glaucoma is an acute secondary angle-closure glaucoma due to anterior subluxation or dislocation of the lens into the anterior chamber and spherophakia. Examination reveals a shallow anterior chamber.

questions.text: A primigravida presents to you with anemia early in her pregnancy. She is 7 weeks pregnant as seen on ultrasound. Her hemoglobin level is 9 g/dL. When should she start taking iron supplements?
questions.solution:
The iron supplements for the 7-week pregnant mother presenting with anemia should be started at 8 to 10 weeks.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention defined anemia in pregnant women using a cut-off value. The pregnant mother is said to be anemic when the level of haemoglobin is less than 11 g/dL in the first and third trimesters and less than 10.5 g/dL in the second trimester.

Anemia in the first trimester is treated by oral iron therapy. According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat program, pregnant women with mild and moderate anemia are treated with two iron and folic acid tablets. Each tablet contains 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid. These tablets are taken daily and are supplied by the healthcare worker. Hence, in this mother iron supplementation should be started by 8-10 weeks.

Drawbacks of oral therapy are intolerance presenting as epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, constipation, or diarrhea, and unpredictable absorption rate. The improvement in haemoglobin levels is generally evident within 3 weeks of oral iron therapy.Contraindications to oral therapy are intolerance, and severe anemia in advanced pregnancy. In these patients, intravenous iron therapy may be considered.

The best time to start corrective iron therapy in pregnancy depends on the individual patient's needs and the presence of anemia. For most pregnant women without anemia, it is recommended to start iron supplementation between 12-16 weeks of gestation to meet the increased iron demands during pregnancy.If a pregnant woman has anemia, iron supplementation should be started as soon as diagnosed, regardless of the gestational age.

questions.text: An ENT resident performs the following procedure under general anesthesia to wash out the pus in a patient diagnosed with chronic maxillary sinusitis. This patient is usually placed in which of the following positions while performing this procedure?
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the above image is proof puncture (antral lavage). While performing this procedure under general anesthesia, the patient is placed in Rose's position or tonsillectomy position 

Rose position is a surgical position that involves head and neck extension with a sandbag near the shoulder blade as shown in the below image:

Proof puncture (antral lavage): This procedure involves puncturing the medial wall of the maxillary sinus in the region of the inferior meatus and irrigating the sinus.

Indications:

  • Chronic and subacute maxillary sinusitis with dual purpose of confirming the diagnosis and washing out the pus.
  • To collect the specimen of the antral contents for culture and sensitivity, or cytological examination to exclude early malignancy.

Contraindications:

  • Acute maxillary sinusitis for fear of osteomyelitis

Note: Sitting position is preferred in all adults when using local anesthesia. But under general anesthesia, the patient is placed in Rose's position or tonsillectomy position


Other options:

Option B: Barking-dog position is a surgical position in which the neck is flexed on the thorax and the head is extended on atlanto-occipital joint. This position is used during laryngoscopy, bronchoscopy, and oesophagoscopy.


Option C: Reverse Trendelenburg position is lying flat with the head 15 - 30 degrees higher than the feet. This position is used in ocular and ENT surgeries like minimally invasive cataract surgery and rhinoplasty.


Option D: Semi fowler position is lying supine incline at an angle of 30 - 45 degrees. This position is used for patients who have cardiac or respiratory conditions and for patients with a nasogastric tube.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male who met with a road traffic accident is brought to the casualty in an unconscious state. On eye examination, the right pupil is constricted, whereas the left pupil is dilated and unresponsive to light. A CT scan reveals left subdural hematoma. What is the ocular sign called?
questions.solution:
Hutchinson's pupil is seen in raised intracranial pressure (ICP) secondary to space-occupying lesions. The raised ICP compresses the oculomotor nerve and causes pupillary changes. The pupil on the side of the space-occupying lesion is affected first. The changes progress through three stages.

Stage Ipsilateral pupil Mechanism Opposite pupil Mechanism
1 Constricted Oculomotor nerve irritation Normal -
2 Dilated, unreactive to light Oculomotor nerve paralysis Constricted Oculomotor nerve irritation
3 Dilated, unreactive to light Oculomotor nerve paralysis  Dilated, unreactive to light Oculomotor nerve paralysis 

Stage 3 indicates that the ICP is very high. Immediate cerebral decompression should be done in such patients.

Other options:

Option B: Marcus Gunn pupil, both direct and consensual light reflexes are blunted when light is shone in the affected eye. This is due to a relative afferent pupilary defect (RAPD) seen in optic nerve lesions and severe retinal diseases. It is tested by the swinging flashlight test.

Option C: Adie’s pupil is caused by postganglionic parasympathetic lesions of the oculomotor nerve. The affected pupil is larger, light reflex is sluggish, and near reflex is slow and tonic. The contralateral pupil is normal.

Option D: Wernicke’s heminanopic pupil is seen in lesions of the optic tract. Direct and consensual light reflexes are absent when light is shone on the temporal retina of the ipsilateral eye and nasal retina of the contralateral eye.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male with a history of respiratory tract infection 4 weeks ago is unable to stand or walk for the past 2 weeks and the weakness is progressive, ascending, and symmetrical in nature. The lower limbs were involved before and gradually the upper limbs were also affected. On examination you note areflexia. Pain and proprioception are preserved. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS).

GBS is an acute, fulminant polyradiculoneuropathy that is autoimmune in nature. GBS is caused when immune response/antibodies against external antigens like infections, vaccines, etc target similar proteins present in the person's nervous tissue.

Clinical features are rapidly evolving areflexic motor paralysis with or without sensory disturbance. Respiration is compromised when it involves respiratory muscles. In such cases, ventilatory support is needed.

High-dose intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) or plasmapheresis are equally effective for typical GBS. IVIg is the initial therapy chosen because of its ease of administration and good safety record.

Other options:

Option B: Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular disorder due to autoimmune damage to the acetylcholine receptors. It is characterized by weakness and muscle fatiguability. Weakness increases with usage. Ocular features like ptosis and diplopia can be seen. Proximal limb weakness is also present. 

Option C: Polymyositis is one of the inflammatory myopathies characterized by symmetric and proximal muscle weakness. This weakness usually worsens over several weeks to months. It is more common in women. Most patients improve with immunotherapies, but they require lifelong treatment.

Option D: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune demyelinating disease characterized by multiple episodes of neurological deficits due to patchy white matter lesions that involve various sites of the brain. It is caused by an autoimmune response directed against components of the myelin sheath. The demyelinated plaques are the hallmark of MS

 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of Immunopathogenesis of Guillain-Barre Syndrome

The following sequence of events, takes into consideration, the development of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) associated with Campylobacter jejuni infection.

  1. B cells recognize glycoconjugates on jejuni (Cj) that cross-react with ganglioside present on Schwann cell surface and subjacent peripheral nerve myelin.
  2. Most of the B cells are activated via a partially T cell–dependent route and secrete primarily IgG autoantibodies. Some B cells, activated via a T cell–independent mechanism, secrete primarily IgM
  3. The activated B cells escape from Peyer’s patches into regional lymph nodes.
  4. Activated T cells also function to assist in the opening of the blood-nerve barrier, facilitating penetration of pathogenic autoantibodies.
  5. The earliest changes in myelin consist of edema between myelin lamellae and vesicular disruption of the outermost myelin layers.
  6. These effects are associated with activation of the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex and mediated by calcium entry; it is possible that the macrophage cytokine tumor necrosis factor (TNF) also participates in myelin damage.

questions.text: A 35-year-old G2P1 at 38 weeks of gestation came to the labor room with complaints of decreased fetal movements.  A non-stress test was done and variable decelerations are noted.  It indicates ______
questions.solution:
Variable deceleration indicates Umbilical cord compression.

Deceleration: Decrease in fetal heart rate below the baseline by 15 bpm for more than 15s.

The non-stress test is a screening test used in the assessment of fetal well-being. It measures fetal heart rate and uterine contractions during pregnancy.

On conducting a NST:

  • Reactive NST: When 2 or more accelerations of more than 15 beats per minute above the baseline and longer than 15 seconds in duration are present in a 20 minute observation then reassure patient and send back home.
  • Non-reactive NST: When there is an absence of any fetal reactivity Biophysical profile(BPP) has to be assessed.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primi,  visits your clinic for regular antenatal check-up at 37 weeks of gestation. You perform the following grip by facing the feet of the patient. This  is known as
questions.solution:
The obstetric grip shown in the picture is the Fourth Leopold maneuver (also known as pelvic grip) and it is used to detect the degree of descent. This examination is done by facing the patient’s feet.

Fetal pole, lie, presenting part, engagement, and attitude of fetal head are assessed by Leopold's manoeuvres:

First Leopold (Fundal grip ):

  • Performed by facing the patient’s face
  • Assesses the uterine fundus.
  • Helps in identification of fetal lie and determination of fetal pole at the fundus.
  • The breech gives the sensation of a large, irregular mass. 
  • The head feels hard and round and is more mobile.

Second Leopold (Lateral grip ): 

  • Performed by facing the patient’s face
  • Assesses the fetal orientation.
  • The palms are placed on either side of the maternal abdomen, and gentle but deep pressure is exerted.
  • The back is felt on one side as a hard, resistant structure.
  • The fetal extremities are felt on the other side as numerous small, irregular, mobile parts are felt.
  • Fetal orientation can be determined by noting whether the back is directed anteriorly, transversely, or posteriorly.
  • The position of the anterior shoulder is mainly assessed by this grip.

Pawlik's grip (third Leopold):

  • Performed by facing the patient’s face.
  • Assesses the presenting part in respect to the true pelvis.
  • The thumb and fingers of one hand grasp the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis.
  • If the presenting part is not engaged it can be grasped distinctly.

Pelvic grip (fourth Leopold):

  • Assesses the engagement, attitude of the fetal head and determines the degree of descent.
  • The examiner faces the mother's feet, and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either side of the presenting part.
  • They exert inward pressure and then slide along the axis of the pelvic inlet.
  • It is the only grip performed facing the feet.

questions.text: While performing an inguinal hernia repair in a 3-year-old boy, you notice Meckel’s diverticulum as the content of the hernial sac. What is this hernia called?
questions.solution:
Meckel’s diverticulum found in inguinal or femoral hernial sacs is known as Littre's hernia. It can cause intestinal obstruction.

Option A: Amyand’s hernia is an inguinal hernia in which the hernia sac contains a normal or acutely inflamed appendix.

Option B: Narath’s hernia is seen in patients with congenital dislocation of the hip. It is a femoral hernia seen behind the femoral vessels.

Option C: Cloquet’s hernia is a type of femoral hernia where the sac lies under the pectineus fascia.

questions.text: A male patient complains of loss of appetite and dysphagia. He lost around significant amount weight in the last few months. The clinician suspects an esophageal condition. Which of the following is the gold standard investigation method in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a significant weight loss and other symptoms of cachexia and anorexia most likely has esophageal carcinoma. Endoscopy and biopsy of the lesion (gold standard) are performed to diagnose esophageal carcinoma.

Esophageal carcinoma is more commonly seen in men. Tobacco use and alcohol are strong risk factors. Adenocarcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus are the two most common types. The squamous cell variant usually affects the upper two-thirds and the adenocarcinoma variant usually affects the lower third. The incidence of adenocarcinoma is increasing.

Clinical features include:

  • Dysphagia (most common)
  • Regurgitation
  • Vomiting
  • Odynophagia
  • Weight loss

In the advanced stage, there can be hoarseness of voice due to recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy, horner’s syndrome, chronic spinal pain, and diaphragmatic paralysis.

Flexible endoscopy with biopsy is preferred for confirmation of diagnosis. Other investigations include barium swallow, which shows a rat-tail appearance due to irregular narrowing or ulceration. Contrast-enhanced CT and PET can be used to assess distant metastasis. Endoscopic ultrasonography (EUS) is the investigation of choice to assess tumor invasion and lymph node metastasis.

questions.text: Hematogenous spread of carcinoma prostate occurs predominantly to the______.
questions.solution:
The hematogenous spread of carcinoma prostate occurs predominantly in the bones and is typically osteoblastic.

Batson venous plexus is a valveless vertebral venous plexus communicating with the prostatic venous plexus. Carcinoma of the prostate metastasizes to the bone usually by the bloodstream through this Batson plexus. The bones most frequently involved are the pelvic bones and the lower lumbar vertebrae. The femoral head, ribcage and skull are other common sites. Other routes of spread of prostate carcinoma are local spread to the seminal vesicles, bladder neck, trigone, and lymphatic spread.

Carcinoma of the prostate is the most common malignancy in men above 65 years. The clinical features of prostate cancer are bladder outlet obstruction, pelvic pain, hematuria, arthritis, anaemia, and renal failure. Per rectal examination reveals a hard, nodular, irregularly indurated gland. 

Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is useful in assessing the follow-up. PSA >10 ng/mL is suggestive of cancer and levels >35 ng/mL are diagnostic of advanced prostate cancer. The prostatic biopsy is indicated when there is a raised PSA level or suspicion of prostate cancer.

Localized cancer is treated by radical prostatectomy and radiation therapy, while in advanced cancer palliative and hormone ablation should be carried out. 

Related Pearl: Types of metastasis(osteoblastic or osteolytic) and their primary:

Predominantly osteoblastic:

  • Prostate cancer
  • Osteosarcoma 
  • Medullary carcinoma thyroid

Mixed osteoblastic and osteolytic:

  • Breast cancer(preponderance toward osteolytic)
  • Lymphoma
  • Urothelial carcinoma 
  • Lung cancer

Predominantly osteolytic:

  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Multiple myeloma 
  • Thyroid carcinoma(except medullary carcinoma thyroid)
  • Gastrointestinal tract carcinoma
  • Malignant melanoma

questions.text: An 11-month-old baby boy has an empty scrotum on the right side with normal left testis. But a mass was palpable on the right inguinal canal. Ultrasonography revealed the right testicle under the subcutaneous fat near the right inguinal canal with a normal left testis. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of cryptorchidism and the next best step is to perform an orchidopexy.

Orchidopexy is the treatment of choice for incompletely palpable unilateral undescended testis. Orchidopexy is usually performed before the boy reaches 12 months of age to avoid the following complications remembered by the mnemonic TESTIS:

T- Torsion
E- Epididymorchitis
S- Sterility
T- Trauma (Increased risk)
I- Increased risk of inguinal hernia (Most commonly occurring complication)
S- Seminoma (Increased risk)

About 4% of boys are born with one or both testes incompletely descended. About two-thirds of these reach the scrotum during the first 3 months of life, but full descent after that is uncommon.

Cryptorchidism is the failure of the descent of the intra-abdominal testes into the scrotal sac.  It is the most common congenital abnormality of the genitourinary tract. The testes can arrest anywhere during descent, and the most common site is the inguinal region.

Phases of testicular descent:

  • Transabdominal phase: Testes come to lie in the lower abdomen or pelvis, and this descent is regulated by Mullerian-inhibiting substances.
  • Inguinoscrotal phase: Testes descend along the inguinal canal and reach the scrotal sac, and this phase of the descent is regulated by androgen-induced calcitonin gene-related peptide from the genitofemoral nerve.

The exact pathogenesis remains unknown; however, deficiency in gonadotropins and Mullerian-inhibiting substance (MIS) and increased expression of estradiol in the placenta are thought to play a role. 

Cryptorchidism is histopathologically characterized by the following: 

  1. Testicular atrophy: thickening of the basement membrane, arrested germ cell development, marked hyalinization
  2. Tubules showing Sertoli cells but no spermatogenesis
  3. Increase in the interstitial Leydig cells 
Other options:

Option A: Cryptorchidism is associated with testicular atrophy and dysfunction, which result in sterility. Cryptorchid testes carry a 3–5-fold higher risk for testicular cancer (usually seminoma). Thus, observation is never the policy.
 
Option B: When the testis is not palpable, ultrasound may be helpful in identifying the intracanalicular testis, while laparoscopy may be needed to differentiate between the abdominal testis and a truly absent testis. Since here testis is made out in the inguinal region, laparoscopy is not the next best line of management.
 
Option D: Orchidectomy should be considered if the incompletely descended testis is atrophic, particularly in the postpubertal boy if the other testis is normal.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male patient with a history of smoking presented with a painless palpable mass in the parotid region. The biopsy of the mass is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical presentation and histopathological slide showing epithelial elements with lymphoid infiltration are suggestive of a Warthin tumor (papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum) of the parotid gland.

Warthin tumor is the second most common salivary gland neoplasm. It is seen in elderly male smokers. It is a benign, well-encapsulated cystic tumor.

The gross appearance of these tumors shows round to oval encapsulated masses, easily palpable in the superficial parotid. Transection reveals a pale grey surface punctuated by cleft-like spaces filled with mucinous or serous secretions.

Histologically, the tumor shows epithelial and lymphoid elements. The epithelium typically consists of a double layer of oncocytic epithelial cells, with an inner columnar layer and an outer cuboidal layer.

Other options:

Option A: Adenoid cystic carcinoma is poorly encapsulated infiltrative carcinoma involving minor salivary glands, commonly the palatine glands. Histology shows tumor cells, organized in a cribriform growth pattern, resembling Swiss cheese. The image is shown below.

Option C: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the salivary gland, commonly affecting the parotid gland. Many are associated with a balanced t(11;19)(q21;p13) chromosomal translocation. Histology shows mucinous, intermediate, and squamous elements, with small to large mucus-filled vacuoles. Image is shown below.

Option D: Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common salivary gland neoplasms. The parotid gland is most commonly involved. They are benign tumors that consist of a mixture of ductal (epithelial), myoepithelial, and mesenchymal cells. Image is shown below.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: Which one of the following is NOT a feature of refeeding syndrome?
questions.solution:
Refeeding syndrome is associated with Hypophosphataemia, hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia.

Refeeding syndrome is a potentially lethal condition that can occur with rapid and excessive feeding of patients with severe underlying malnutrition due to starvation, alcoholism, delayed nutritional support, anorexia nervosa, or massive weight loss in obese patients.

  • It can occur with either enteral or parenteral nutrition, but is more common with the latter.
  • Symptoms: Electrolyte abnormalities can result in cardiac failure and dysrrhythmias, respiratory failure, neu­rologic disturbances, and renal and hepatic dysfunction.

Prevention and treatment:

  • Correct underlying electrolyte and volume deficits.
  • Additionally, thiamine should be administered before the initiation of feeding. Caloric replenition should be instituted slowly and should gradually increase over the first week.
  • Vital signs, fluid balance, and electrolytes should be closely monitored and any deficits corrected as they evolve.

questions.text: A 24-year-old lady in her third week postpartum complains of pain in her left breast. She also complains of mild fever, headache, and nausea. Examination reveals a tender breast with red, hot, and flushed overlying skin. There is no fluctuant swelling or discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of a lactating mother presenting with breast pain, fever, headache, nausea, and tender breast with red, hot, and flushed overlying skin points towards a diagnosis of acute mastitis.

The most common organism involved in acute mastitis is Staphylococcus aureus. Other organisms involved are Staphylococcus epidermidis, and Streptococci viridans. The source of organisms is the infant’s nose and throat. It usually occurs during the first 2–4 weeks postpartum.

Clinical features:

  • Generalized malaise
  • Headache
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Fever with chills
  • Severe pain and, non-fluctuant swelling.
  • The overlying skin is red, hot, and flushed, and feels tense and tender

Microscopic examination of breast milk shows leucocytes >106/mL and bacterial count >103/mL. It might lead to the formation of a breast abscess.

Management:

  • Breast support and analgesics
  • Breastfeeding is continued. The infected side is emptied manually with each feed.
  • Dicloxacillin is the drug of choice
  • Erythromycin is given to patients who are allergic to penicillin

Other options:

Option A - Breast engorgement occurs due to exaggerated normal venous and lymphatic engorgement of the breasts which precedes lactation. It is characterized by bilateral breast tenderness and swelling typically present 24 to 72 hours post-partum, peaks 3 to 5 days after delivery and resolves spontaneously. Antibiotics are not indicated. Treatment is by cold compresses and analgesics.

Option B - A galactocele is a milk-filled cavity in the breast of a woman who is usually lactating. It can be caused due to lactation problems, prolactin stimulation by drugs, or duct obstruction. It presents as a palpable, round, well-circumscribed, and freely mobile mass with no fever, pain, or inflammation. It is usually subareolar and unilateral.

Option C - Breast abscess is usually suspected when there is no response to treatment for mastitis in 48-72 hours. It is also characterised by brawny oedema over the affected area, fluctuant lump. Management includes sonography-guided needle aspiration under local anaesthesia. Antibiotics and pumping of the affected breast are also done. Incision and drainage of the abscess are done in cases not responding to aspiration.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with complete obstruction of his left nostril and a nodule on the dorsum of the nose obscuring his vision as shown in the image. He gives a typical history of foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge with crust formation even before this nodule developed. Histology of the biopsied specimen is given as an image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is suggestive of rhinoscleroma.

It can be diagnosed as rhinoscleroma, as the patient had a history of purulent foul-smelling nasal discharge with crusting before the development of nodule, which corresponds to the atrophic stage of rhinoscleroma 

Adding to this, the given histology shows large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing the causative bacilli, which are Mikulicz cells

Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus).

It has 3 stages

Atrophic stage– Crusting and foul-smelling nasal discharge similar to atrophic rhinitis.

Granulomatous stage– Painless, non-ulcerative Granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving the feel of woody/hebra nose.

Cicatricial stage – Fibrosis leading to stenosis of vestibule, pharynx, larynx. The deformity is called tapir nose.

Treatment: Streptomycin (1g/day) and tetracycline (2g/day) are given together for a period of 4 to 6 weeks. Steroids can be combined with this to reduce fibrosis. Surgical treatment is necessary to restore the airway and correction of the nasal deformity.

Other options:

Option A: Even though the inner canthus of the eye is a common site for the occurrence of basal cell carcinoma, the given histology does not show palisade of the basaloid epithelium, which is very classical of BCC

Option B: Rhinophyma or potato tumour is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous gland and presents as swelling over tip of the nose.

Option C: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass

questions.text: A 44-year-old man who works as an operator in the CT room is being evaluated for radiation exposure using the equipment shown below. Which of the following is not a constituent of this badge?
questions.solution:
The given shows a TLD badge (thermoluminescent dosimeter) which is used for personal radiation dose monitoring. Lead is not a constituent of this badge.

Lead is not a component of the TLD badge but lead is used to offer radiation shielding. Lead aprons are commonly used to safeguard from scattered radiation.

The thermoluminescent material used in them is calcium sulfate doped with dysprosium or lithium fluoride. The radiation exposure is monitored every 3 months. The badge should be positioned according to local or national practices.

In India, the TLD badge is worn inside the lead apron at the chest level. The maximum dose limit for occupational radiation workers is 30 mSv in a year provided the cumulative dose in a block of 5 years does not exceed 100 mSv. 

Acute Radiation Syndromes (ARS) is an acute illness that is caused by exposure of the entire body to a high dose of penetrating radiation in a very short period of time. It is also known as radiation toxicity or radiation sickness. It consists of three syndromes:

Syndrome   Radiation dose
Hematopoietic
(Bone marrow)		  >0.7 Gy  
Gastrointestinal   >10 Gy  
Cardiovascular/ Central nervous system   >50 Gy  

Stages of ARS include: 

  • Prodromal phase - manifests with non-specific symptoms like nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. Early and persistent symptoms predict severity.
  • Latent phase - the patient looks and feels generally healthy for a few hours or even up to a few weeks. In severe cases, this phase may be absent.
  • Manifest illness phase - symptoms are seen as per the radiation dose. Tissues with greater rates of cellular division are most radiosensitive, and hence the hematopoietic and gastrointestinal systems are the most affected.
  • Recovery phase or Death - this begins when the patient recovers from the acute exposure.

questions.text: A farmer presenting with high-grade fever, rash, vomiting, retro orbital pain and myalgia since 5 days is suspected to have dengue hemorrhagic fever. Which of the following investigations can be done to diagnose this condition?

choices.text: Viral isolation of Aedes albopictus ‎(C6/36) culture

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is of a farmer with suspected dengue hemorrhagic fever. As he has presented 5 days after the onset of symptoms, the most appropriate test for him would be IgM ELISA. NS1 antigen is the preferred test had he presented before 5 days. 

Dengue is an acute febrile illness caused by the dengue virus that is transmitted by the Aedes aegypti mosquito. 

It presents as sudden-onset fever, retroorbital pain, myalgia, arthralgia, and a rash. The initial rash in dengue may appear as flushing erythema of the face in the first 2 days of symptoms. A second rash occurs 3-6 days after the onset of fever and appears maculopapular or morbilliform. Sometimes, lesions may coalesce and appear as 'white islands in a red sea' due to generalized erythema with petechiae and islands of sparing.

Before day 5 of illness, during the febrile period, dengue infections may be diagnosed by detection of viral antigens like non-structural viral protein antigen(NS 1) by ELISA or rapid tests. This is considered the mainstay of diagnosis.

Virus isolation in cell culture and viral RNA detection by nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT) can also be done.

Serological tests, such as IgM ELISA, are performed after day 5 when dengue viruses and antigens are no longer present in the blood due to the appearance of specific antibodies.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency with syncope. His BP is 80/60 mmHg, SpO2 is 94%, and respiratory rate is 16 cycles/min. His ECG findings are shown below. He received 3 mg of intravenous atropine, however, there is no improvement in his condition. What is the next best step in the management?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows bradycardia (heart rate ~30 bpm) with no relation between the P and QRS waves, suggestive of third-degree AV block. The next best step is immediate transcutaneous pacing.

Symptomatic bradycardia is defined as having a heart rate of less than 50 beats per minute, for which third-degree heart block is one of the causes. In third-degree heart block, there is a complete failure of conduction between the atria and ventricles. As a result, the atria depolarize in response to SA node activity, while a more distal escape rhythm drives the ventricles independently. Depending on the site of the escape rhythm, the QRS complexes may be of a normal width and occur at 40 to 60 bpm or may be widened and occur at slower rates. 

In adults, the most common causes are acute myocardial infarction and chronic degeneration of the conduction pathways with advanced age. As a result of the slow rate, patients frequently experience fatigue, shortness of breath and syncope.

Other options: 

Option A - Repeat atropine IV is not the right option. The maximum dose of atropine to be given is 3mg iv, which the patient has already received.

Option B - Amiodarone is not indicated in the treatment of bradycardia, but rather in ventricular fibrillation and pulseless ventricular tachycardia

Option D - Defibrillation is performed in ventricular fibrillation and pulseless ventricular tachycardia.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female patient came with complaints of floaters and blurring of vision in both eyes for a few weeks.  Fundoscopic examination shows inferior snow banking.  What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a young female presenting with floaters, blurring of vision, and fundoscopy showing snow banking is suggestive of intermediate uveitis or pars planitis

Intermediate uveitis is the inflammation involving pars plana ciliaris, peripheral retina, choroid, and vitreous base. It is predominantly seen in young females and most often presents with floaters and bilateral blurring of vision.

Snow banking is the hallmark of intermediate uveitis. It refers to greyish white fibrovascular plaques over the pars plana, with or without peripheral retinal periphlebitis. This occurs due to the coalescence of snowball opacities.

Other Signs of intermediate uveitis:

  • Snow-ball opacities (Ant’s egg opacities)- typical exudates present near the ora Serrata in the inferior quadrant
  • Few keratic precipitates (KP) due to spillover anterior uveitis

Other options:

Option A: Anterior uveitis or iridocyclitis is the inflammation of tissue from the iris up to the pars plicata of the ciliary body. It is the most common form of uveitis. They present with:

  • Circumcorneal conjunctival hyperemia
  • Aqueous flare  
  • Keratin precipitates (KPs) 
  • Posterior synechiae  

Option C: Posterior uveitis is the inflammation of the choroid with or without inflammation of the retina. They are classified as:

  • Choroiditis  
  • Chorioretinitis  
  • Retinochoroditis  
  • Neuroretinitis  

Option D: Fuchs' uveitis or Fuchs heterochromatic iridocyclitis is a chronic non-granulomatous condition. They are usually unilateral. A difference in color between the iris of both eyes termed heterochromia iridis is characteristically seen here. Posterior synechiae are absent. A characteristic stellate-shaped keratic precipitates are located diffusely over the entire corneal epithelium.

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication to perform a tonsillectomy?

choices.text: At the time of the measles epidemic

questions.solution:
Tonsillectomy is contraindicated in the presence of acute infection in the upper respiratory tract, as bleeding is more likely in the presence of acute infection.

Contraindications for tonsillectomy:

  • Haemoglobin level less than 10 g%.
  • Presence of acute infection in the upper respiratory tract, even acute tonsillitis, as bleeding is more in the presence of acute infection.
  • Children under 3 years of age. They are poor surgical risks.
  • Overt or submucous cleft palate.
  • Bleeding disorders, e.g. leukaemia, purpura, aplastic anaemia or haemophilia.
  • At the time of an epidemic of polio.
  • Uncontrolled systemic disease, e.g. diabetes, cardiac disease, hypertension or asthma.
  • Tonsillectomy is avoided during the period of menses.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents to you with complaints of dryness in the mouth and eyes. Serum testing reveals positive anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies. The test shown in the image below was positive with a score of < 5 mm in 5 minutes without anesthesia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The test shown above is Schirmer's test and the likely diagnosis is Sjögren's syndrome. 

Sjögren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that involves lymphocytic infiltration of the exocrine glands. This manifests as xerostomia (dry mouth) and keratoconjunctivitis sicca (dry eyes). It is associated with autoantibodies anti-Ro/SS-A and anti-La/SS-B.

Keratoconjunctivitis sicca can be diagnosed by Schirmer's test. This test measures the quantity of tears produced. Two marked strips of paper are placed between the globe and the lower eyelid and the patient is instructed to close their eyes for 5 minutes. The tears produced spread along the paper by capillary action. The distance is measured. A score of more than 10 mm is considered to be normal while that of less than 5 mm is considered deficient. 

A number of other systems can be involved as well. For example, atrophic gastritis, esophageal mucosal atrophy, and vaginal dryness. Extraglandular or systemic manifestations can also be present. These manifest as fatigue, arthritis, Raynaud's phenomenon, and myalgia. 

Diagnosis of primary Sjögren's syndrome requires the following: 

  • Eye and/or mouth dryness
  • Eye tests disclose keratoconjunctivitis sicca
  • Mouth evaluation reveals dry oral mucosa and/or
  • Presence of anti-Ro or anti-La autoantibodies

A labial (lip) biopsy is a must to confirm the diagnosis and determine the prognosis. 

Treatment of Sjögren's syndrome is directed at treating the symptoms and complications. Artificial tears can be used for dry eyes and propionic acid gel for vaginal dryness. Pilocarpine can help increase oral secretions and hydroxychloroquine can be used to treat arthritis. 

Related Pearl: Extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome

The extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome are as follows:

  • Non-specific
    • Arthralgia or arthritis - It is the most common extraglandular manifestation. It is usually non-erosive and leads to Jacoud’s arthropathy
    • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Accumulation of peri-epithelial lymphocytes
    • Interstitial lung disease - Most common type is non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
    • Renal tubular acidosis - Distal (type 1) RTA
    • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Immune complex-mediated
    • Small vessel vasculitis - Presents as cutaneous palpable purpura
    • Glomerulonephritis with cryoglobulinemia
    • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Lymphoma
    • Extranodal marginal zone B cell lymphoma of mucosal-associated lymphoid tissue (MALToma).

questions.text: A patient presents to the casualty ward with right lower abdominal pain, nausea, and fever. On examination, there is increased pain in the right lower quadrant when palpating the left lower quadrant. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
The given triad of clinical features, namely fever, nausea, and right lower abdominal pain, is the Murphy triad. It is suggestive of acute appendicitis. Deep palpation of the left iliac fossa can cause pain in the right iliac fossa. This sign is called the Rovsing sign.

This pain is due to the backflow of gases from the colon into the inflamed right intestine when the left lower abdomen is palpated.

Other options:

Option B: Aaron sign-Pain or pressure in epigastrium or anterior chest with persistent firm pressure applied to McBurney’s point. It is seen in acute appendicitis.

Option C: Dunphy sign-pain on coughing.It is seen in acute appendicitis.

Option D: McBurney sign-it refers to deep tenderness at McBurney's point. It is seen in acute appendicitis.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presents with chin protrusion, excessive sweating  as shown in image below and reports that his shoes no longer fit him and his finger ring is getting tightened. Elevated Insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) levels have been observed. Which of the following tests will help to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggest towards the diagnosis of Acromegaly, IGF-1 levels is the screening test and the diagnosis of acromegaly is confirmed by Oral glucose tolerance test.

Acromegaly is a result of growth hormone hypersecretion due to a pituitary adenoma. It can also occur due to extra pituitary lesions. If growth hormone hypersecretion occurs before the fusion of the growth plates at puberty, it leads to gigantism. 

Acral bony overgrowth in acromegaly manifests as frontal bossing, increased hand and foot size, mandibular enlargement, prognathism, and widened space between incisors. Soft tissue swelling results in increased heel pad thickness, coarse facial features, and a large fleshy nose. Generalized visceromegaly is seen including cardiomegaly, macroglossia, thyroid enlargement, etc. Serious complications include diabetes mellitus, obstructive sleep apnoea, and increased risk of colonic polyps and cancer. 

Lab Investigations: Age-matched serum IGF-I levels are elevated in acromegaly. Consequently, an IGF-I level provides a useful laboratory screening measure when clinical features raise the possibility of acromegaly. Owing to the pulsatility of GH secretion, measure- ment of a single random GH level is not useful for the diagnosis or exclusion of acromegaly and does not correlate with disease severity.

The diagnosis of acromegaly is confirmed by demonstrating the failure of GH suppression to <0.4 μg/L within 1–2 h of an oral glucose load (75 g). When newer ultrasensitive GH assays are used, normal nadir GH levels are even lower (<0.05 μg/L). About 20% of patients exhibit a paradoxical GH rise after glucose. 

Acromegaly can be treated by transsphenoidal resection of the tumor. It can also be managed medically by using octreotide (a somatostatin analog), pegvisomant (Growth Hormone receptor antagonist), dopamine agonists or radiation.

 

Related Pearl: Tests for Acromegaly

Screening test:

The single best test for the diagnosis of acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). A normal serum IGF-1 concentration is strong evidence that the patient does not have acromegaly.

Confirmatory test:

GH suppression test: 75 g of oral glucose (OGTT- oral glucose tolerance test) is administered to the patient. Blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, 120 min (i.e over 2 hours) after the glucose load. Normally, glucose suppresses GH and it falls to <1 ng/mL. If GH >1 ng/mL, it is diagnostic of acromegaly.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant lady at 32 weeks of gestation presents with vaginal discharge associated with itching and burning. On examination, the following finding is seen. Which of the following can be used in the treatment of this patient?

choices.text: Tab. Metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days

questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the image showing curdy white vaginal discharge is suggestive of monilial vaginitis/vaginal candidiasis. A single dose of fluconazole 150 mg can be used in the treatment of this condition.

Local intravaginal application of antifungal agents such as imidazole, miconazole, clotrimazole, butoconazole or ter­conazole vaginal pessaries or creams used for 3–6 days is also very effective. Since the use of fluconazole has been associated with embryotoxicity and increased risk of cardiac malformations, it is recommended to be avoided during the first trimester.

Risk factors for candidal infection include pregnancy, medications such as oral contraceptive pills, steroids, HIV, and diabetes mellitus. Clinical features include itching, curdy-white discharge, burning, and dysuria with vaginal pH <4.5. 

The diagnosis can be confirmed by microscopic examination of the smear of vaginal discharge with 10% KOH solution. The smear shows budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae. Culture can be done on Sabouraud's agar and Nickerson's medium.

Treatment includes control and elimination of risk factors including maintaining personal hygiene, adequate control of diabetes, and stopping contributing medications, in addition to pharmacotherapy as mentioned above. Routine treatment of the partner is not recommended unless the partner is symptomatic.

Other options:

Option A- Metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days is used in the treatment of vaginosis/bacterial vaginitis/nonspecific vaginitis.

Option B- Azithromycin 1 g single dose is used in the treatment of chlamydial infections and chancroid caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

Option D- Metronidazole 2 g single dose is used in the treatment of vaginosis/bacterial vaginitis/nonspecific vaginitis.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy who is a known case of protein C deficiency presents with a painful limp on the right side. His parents give a history of limping after he comes home from playing, 1 week back. On examination,  he is afebrile. The boy whines with pain during passive movement of the hip. The range of motion is restricted in the abduction and internal rotation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Perthes disease.

Perthes disease, also known as Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, is the avascular necrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis. It is most commonly seen in the age group of 4-8 years. The incidence is more in boys than girls. It is usually unilateral disease but can occur bilaterally in 10% of the cases. Risk factors include low birth weight, passive smoking, family history, low socioeconomic status, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Perthes disease is associated with thrombophilia, protein C and S deficiencies.

The disease is characterized by the disruption of blood flow to the femoral head due to which the bone goes for osteonecrosis and stops growing. The lateral epiphyseal artery, a branch of the medial circumflex femoral artery is involved. Over time, healing and fibrosis occur by new blood vessels infiltrating the dead bone and removing the necrotic bone which leads to a loss of bone mass and weakening of the femoral head. 

Clinical features include pain and limping. Pain aggravates on doing any activity and relieves by rest. Physical examination reveals pain on passive movement of the hip and abduction with internal rotation movement is limited.

Xray findings depend on the stages 

  • Initial phase: Medial joint space widening and increased density in the ossific nucleus
  • Fragmentation phase: Alternating patches of sclerosis and fibrosis
  • Re-ossification phase: Complete removal of necrotic bone. Epiphyseal density is regained in this phase
  • Remodelling phase: Remodelling occurs until skeletal maturity is attained

The below radiograph shows features of bone necrosis followed by remodelling in Perthes disease.

Treatment:

Children under 6 years - symptomatic treatment including activity modification, reduction in weight-bearing, abduction bracing, bisphosphonates

Children aged 6-8 years - Operative management with proximal femoral varus osteotomy

For children aged 9 and above - operative management with pelvic osteotomy

Other options:

Option A- Developmental dysplasia of the hip is usually diagnosed in the neonatal period. The hip will be in extension and adduction with limited abduction movement. In children of walking age, a waddling or Trendelenberg gait can be seen. 

Option B- Slipped capital femoral epiphysis occurs most likely in the age group of 10-15 years with an associated endocrinal disorder.

Option D- Septic arthritis can be ruled as the boy is afebrile in the given scenario. It presents as severe tenderness and all movements are abolished due to muscle spasm.

questions.text:
A student is referred by the school nurse with complaints of recurrent headaches and inability to read from the classroom board. There is no diplopia. Examination shows a refractive error of -1D in the right eye and an error of -3D in the left eye. What is your diagnosis?

D - dioptre
questions.solution:
The history of defective vision and 2 different refractive errors of the eyes suggests a diagnosis of anisometropia.

Anisometropia occurs when the total refraction of both eyes are unequal. A difference of 1D in the two eyes causes a 2% difference in the size of retinal images formed. A difference up to 2.5D is well-tolerated, but beyond 4D cannot be tolerated. Anisometropia can occur as a combination of emmetropia, myopia, hypermetropia, and astigmatism.

It is diagnosed after retinoscopic examination and autorefractometry. 

Treatment includes the usage of spectacles (it can be tolerated up to a maximum difference of 4D), contact lenses, intraocular lenses (for uniocular aphakia), refractive corneal surgery, or refractive lens exchange methods (used in high degree anisometropia).

Other options: 

Option B: Aniseikonia occurs when the images that are projected to the visual cortex are abnormally unequal in size. A high degree of anisometropia can also cause anisekonia. However, here the student has a refractive difference of only 2D.

Option C: Irregular astigmatism is the irregular change of refractive power that occur in different meridians. Patients complain of polyopia (seeing multiple images), distortion of objects and defective vision. It is assosciated with corneal irregularities and keratoconus.

Option D: Emmetropia is defined as an optically normal eye where the parallel rays of light coming from infinity focuses at the retina with accomodation at rest.

questions.text: A patient presents with bilateral nasal obstruction. On anterior rhinoscopy, multiple smooth pale glistening masses are found bilaterally suggestive of ethmoidal polyps. The surgeon plans functional endoscopic sinus surgery to remove them. Which of the following structures shown in the image given below is removed during infundibulotomy?
questions.solution:
The image above shows the computed tomography (CT) scan of the ostiomeatal complex in the coronal plane. The structure marked as 1 is the uncinate process which is removed in infundibulotomy.

Infundibulotomy, also known as uncinectomy, is the first surgical step in functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS). FESS is the treatment of choice for ethmoidal polyps, which this patient has.

The structure marked as 2 is the ethmoidal bulla, and is removed in bullectomy.

The structure marked as 3 is the middle turbinate

The structure marked as 4 is the medial wall of the maxillary sinus.

Important steps in FESS:

  1. Uncinectomy or Infundibulotomy
  2. Identification and enlargement of the maxillary ostium
  3. Bullectomy
  4. Penetration of basal lamella and posterior ethmoidal cells
  5. Clearance of frontal recess and frontal sinusotomy
  6. Sphenoidotomy
  7. Nasal packing

Indications of FESS:

  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis refractory to medical treatment.
  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis.
  • Polypoid rhinosinusitis.
  • Fungal sinusitis with fungal ball.
  • Antrochoanal polyp.
  • Mucocele of frontoethmoid or sphenoid sinus.
  • Endoscopic septoplasty.
  • Epistaxis control by endoscopic cautery.
  • Foreign body removal from the nose or sinus.

Related Pearl: Ethmoidal polyps

  • Main etiological factor is allergy
  • Usually affects the middle-aged
  • Site of origin: Lateral wall of the nose
  • Clinical features: Nasal stuffiness, headache (due to sinusitis), sneezing, watery nasal discharge, anosmia/ hyposmia, mass protruding from the nasal cavity
  • Findings:
    • Anterior rhinoscopy: Multiple, bilateral polypi that are smooth, glistening, grape-like masses often pale in color
    • They may be sessile or pedunculated, insensitive to probing and do not bleed on touch
  • Investigation of choice: NCCT
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text:
A 2-year-old child suffered a cut on his hand while playing. An anxious mother brought him to the hospital when she noticed that the bleeding from the wound did not stop even after half an hour. Lab investigation reports are given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?

Platelet count- normal
Fibrinogen levels- normal
Prothrombin time- normal
Activated partial thromboplastin time- prolonged
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of profuse bleeding from minor wounds, prolonged APTT, with normal PT and platelet count suggests Von Willebrand disease as the most probable diagnosis.

Von Willebrand disease (VWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder which occurs due to deficiency of or defect in von Willebrand factor (vWF). vWF is stored in endothelial cells and in platelet Weibel-Palade bodies. It has two important functions:

  • Adhesion of the platelets to injured subendothelium
  • Carrier protein for factor VIII and preventing its degradation

Clinical features include spontaneous bleeding from mucous membranes (epistaxis), excessive bleeding from wounds, or menorrhagia, after dental extractions and surgeries including tonsillectomies. Most individuals are asymptomatic otherwise. Type 3 VWD is the most severe form and presents with symptoms like joint bleeds, similar to those seen in mild hemophilia.

Diagnosis

  • Normal platelet count
  • Prolonged BT
  • Normal PT
  • Prolonged aPTT

Factor VIII is found bound to the Von-Willebrand factor(vWF) in the blood. Deficiency of vWF results in Factor VIII deficiency and prolongation of aPTT in this disease. Prolonged BT is due to abnormal platelet-mediated hemostasis.

Classification

Three types are recognized, with phenotypic variations:

Type 1 and type 3 von Willebrand disease are associated with quantitative defects in vWF.

Type 1 is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by a mild to moderate vWF deficiency, accounting for about 70% of all cases. 

Type 3 disease is an autosomal recessive disorder resulting in little to no vWF synthesis. Because vWF stabilizes factor VIII in the circulation, factor VIII levels are also reduced in type 3 disease and the associated bleeding disorder is often severe.

Type 2 von Willebrand disease is characterized by qualitative defects in vWF. Type 2A is the most common. It is inherited as an autosomal dominant disorder.

Treatment: Desmopressin for type 1 vWD stimulates the release of vWF and Factor VIII from the endothelial stores. Von Willebrand factor (VWF) concentrates in cases of type 2 and type 3 von Willebrand disease.

Other options-

Options A and B: Bernard–Soulier syndrome and Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia are caused due to deficiency of Gp Ib-IX receptor and deficiency Gp IIb/IIIa receptor respectively. In both these conditions, PTT is normal, with only an increase in bleeding time.

Option C: Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura is characterized by the pentad of fever, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, abnormal renal function, and central nervous system (CNS). Occurs due to deficiency of ADAMTS13.
