questions.text: What is the mode of insertion of this contraceptive?
questions.solution:
The image shows an Essure coil which is inserted hysteroscopically to occlude both the fallopian tubes.

Essure(not yet licensed in India):

  • It is a spring-like device introduced using a hysteroscope inserted through the vagina into the uterus and then into each fallopian tube.
  • In 3 months' time, scar tissue grows into the device and plugs the fallopian tube; hence, sperms cannot pass through to fertilize an egg.
  • Made of nickel and titanium alloy and is considered irreversible.
  • Contraindicated in patients who are uncertain about ending fertility, can have only one insert placed (including contralateral proximal tubal occlusion or suspected unicornuate uterus), an abnormal uterine cavity that makes visualization of the tubal ostia impossible, and/or abnormal tubal anatomy or previous tubal ligation (including failed ligation), pregnant or suspect pregnancy, delivered or terminated a pregnancy less than 6 weeks, an active upper or lower genital tract infection, unexplained vaginal bleeding, a gynecological malignancy, known allergy to contrast media.
  • Side effects-cramping, nausea/vomiting, back pain, abdominal pain, and dyspareunia.

questions.text:
Match the following instruments used in surgery.
  1. Allis tissue forceps
  2. Lane’s tissue holding forceps
  3. Kocher’s hemostatic forceps
  4. Babcock’s forceps
questions.solution:
Option 2 is correctly matched.

Image 1 shows Lane’s tissue holding forceps

  • It has got stout and thick distal blades with oval fenestra in each blade
  • Apposing tooth in the tip
  • Lock in proximal part

Uses:

  • Hold bulky and tough structures, hold lymph nodes.

 

Image 2 shows Allis tissue forceps.

  • Distal blades are not opposing each other
  • Tip has got teeth in each blade which are opposing
  • Lock in proximal part

Uses:

  • Hold Skin flaps, Fascia, Aponeurosis, Bladder wall.

 

Image 3 shows Babcock’s forceps where:

  • Distal part of distal blade is curved with a triangular fenestra which allows soft tissues to bulge out.
  • Tip is non-traumatic with transverse serrations on it.
  • It has got a lock in the proximal part.

Uses:

  • Hold any part of Bowel, Fallopian tube, Appendix, Ureter, Cord, etc.

 

Image 4 shows Kocher’s hemostatic forceps.

Apposing tooth in the tip and serrations in the distal blades.

Uses:

  • Hold pedicles, tough structures, cut ends of muscles
  • Hold ribs during rib dissection, hold gauze for blunt dissection, hold resected bowel.

questions.text:
A patient is on total parenteral nutrition for more than a month via a central venous catheter. All are done except _____.

LFT- Liver function tests

BUN- blood urea nitrogen

choices.text: Sudden glucose intolerance is an early sign of sepsis
Electrolytes must be checked every 2-3 days
LFT, BUN must be done once weekly
Change central venous catheter tube every two weeks

questions.solution:
Central venous catheter is changed only if an infection is suspected or the catheter is blocked.

Total parenteral nutrition (TPN), also referred to as central parenteral nutrition, requires access to a large-diameter vein to deliver the entire nutritional requirements of the individual.

Complications of TPN:

  • Technical complications:
    • Long-term parenteral feeding is commonly associated with sepsis secondary to contamination of the central venous catheter.
    • Sudden development of glucose intolerance is one of the earliest signs of systemic sepsis.
    • The rate of catheter infection is highest for those placed in the femoral vein, lower for those in the jugular vein, and lowest for those in the subclavian vein.
    • The use of ultrasonographic guidance during central venous line placement decreases the complications.
  • Metabolic complications:
    • Parenterally nourished patient should not be overfed, especially in a depleted patient in whom excess calorie infusion may result in carbon dioxide retention and respiratory insufficiency. Excess feeding can cause hepatic steatosis or marked glycogen deposition in selected patients.
    • Cholestasis and formation of gallstones are common in patients receiving long-term parenteral nutrition.
    • BUN, LFT must be done once weekly and serum electrolytes must be checked every 2-3 days to keep abreast of the metabolic complications.
  • Intestinal atrophy:
    • Lack of intestinal stimulation is associated with intestinal mucosal atrophy, diminished villous height, bacterial overgrowth, reduced lymphoid tissue size, reduced IgA production, and impaired gut immunity.
    • The most efficacious method to prevent these changes is to provide at least some nutrients enterally.

Total parenteral nutrition is a must know for all physicians as it forms one of the most important constituents of critical care.

questions.text: All of the following structures are cut in mediolateral episiotomy except?

choices.text: Transverse perineal branches of pudendal  nerves

questions.solution:
All the above-mentioned structures are cut in mediolateral episiotomy except for the obturator muscle.

Episiotomy: Surgically planned incision on the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labor is called episiotomy. In mediolateral episiotomy, the incision is made downwards and outwards from the midpoint of the fourchette either to the right or to the left.

The other types of episiotomy include median, lateral, and J shaped episiotomy.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles
  • Bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering these muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

  • Begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline, which yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.
  • Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over the median episiotomy.
  • Increased blood loss.
  • Causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic patient presents to you with severe pain and swelling of the left leg. He gives a history of sustaining a thorn prick to his left foot while hiking 5 days ago. The examination of his leg is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of cellulitis.

Cellulitis is a painful, diffuse infection of the dermis and the subcutaneous tissue. It is characterized by poorly demarcated areas of marked edema, dilated superficial capillaries, and extravasation of red blood cells and inflammatory cells into the dermis. Constitutional symptoms like fever and malaise are also present.

It is most commonly caused by beta-haemolytic Streptococci, Staphylococci, and Clostridium perfringens. The point of entry may be a traumatic or surgical wound. Lower limbs are the commonest site of cellulitis and any wound, including tinea pedis or bacterial infection, is a possible site of entry. The face is the next common site of infection.

Parenteral penicillin is the treatment of choice. Other regimens may include antistaphylococcal penicillins, cefazolin, ceftaroline, and ceftriaxone.

Other options:

Option A: Erysipelas is an infection of the superficial epidermis. It presents as an erythematous raised lesion with sharply demarcated edges that differentiate it from the surrounding skin. The given image shows erysipelas.

Option B: Lymphangitis will be evident with visible erythema tracking along lymphatic channels.

Option D: Necrotizing fasciitis is a rapidly progressive necrosis of the subcutaneous tissues and fascia. The source of the infection is either the skin following trauma or a surgical incision. Diabetes mellitus is the most common comorbidity associated with the condition. 

Local symptoms and signs are pain, erythema, edema, warmth, crepitus, blisters, bullae, greyish drainage (dishwater pus), necrosis, and gangrene. Systemic features are fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, shock, coagulopathy, and multiorgan failure. 

Treatment involves appropriate intravenous antibiotics with urgent radical surgical debridement.

questions.text: Most common variant of basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is_____
questions.solution:
The most common form of BCC (60%) is the nodular variant, characterized by

  • Pearly opalescent nodules with central depression with umbilication or ulceration and rolled edges and telangiectasia.
  • Seen in sun-exposed areas of individuals over the age of 60.

Other types are:

  • Superficial BCC (15% of BCC) - typically appears on the trunk as a pink or erythematous plaque with a thin pearly border.
  • Infiltrative form
  • Pigmented variant of nodular BCC - difficult to differentiate from nodular melanoma.
  • Morpheaform variant - indistinct borders with a yellow hue.
  • Fibroepithelioma of Pinkus.
